headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Global Payments Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, today's conference call will be recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conf
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Global Payments Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, today's conference call will be recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to your host, Vice President Investor Relations, Andrew Langford. Please go ahead.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Global Payments' Fiscal 2016 Third Quarter Conference Call. Our call today is scheduled for 1 hour. Joining on the call are Jeff Sloan, CEO; David Mangum, President and CFO; and Cameron Bready, Executive Vice President and CFO
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Global Payments' Fiscal 2016 Third Quarter Conference Call. Our call today is scheduled for 1 hour. Joining on the call are Jeff Sloan, CEO; David Mangum, President and CFO; and Cameron Bready, Executive Vice President and CFO. 
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that some of the comments made by management during today's conference call contains forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties discussed in our SEC filings, including our most recent 10-K and subsequent filings. These risks and uncertainties could cause actual results to differ materially. We caution you not to place undue reliance on these statements. Forward-looking statements made during this call speak only as of the date of this call and we undertake no obligation to update them. In addition, some of these comments made on the call may refer to certain measures, such as cash earnings, adjusted net revenue and free cash flow, which are non-GAAP measures. For full reconciliations of cash earnings, adjusted net revenue and other non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP results in accordance to Regulation G, please see our press release, furnish as an exhibit to our Form 8-K filed this morning and our financial highlights, both of which were available in the Investor Relations area of our website at www.globalpaymentsinc.com. 
Now I'd like to introduce Jeff Sloan. Jeff?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew and thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning. We are pleased to report another quarter of very strong results. We accelerated organic growth across our key markets with particular strength in our United States and United Kingdom bus
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew and thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning. We are pleased to report another quarter of very strong results. We accelerated organic growth across our key markets with particular strength in our United States and United Kingdom businesses, continuing our track record of solid execution globally. Importantly, we are also on track with our pending acquisition of Heartland Payments, which we expect to close later this month. 
For the third quarter of fiscal 2016, we grew net revenue 6%, expanded margins 50 basis points and increased cash earnings per share 17%, all this despite observing significant incremental foreign currency headwinds. On a constant currency basis, each of these metrics exceeded our expectations, reflecting the successful execution of our strategy and operational excellence across the organization. 
Now for more detailed highlights. 
We are especially pleased with our performance in North America where we believe we continue to grow faster than our markets by capturing share in verticals with attractive growth and margin characteristics. 
Organic revenue growth for our U.S. direct business accelerated in the quarter compared to the second quarter of fiscal 2016. OpenEdge continued its streak of mid to high-teens growth. Our gaming business also continue to deliver strong organic growth, coupled with sound execution of the FIS gaming acquisition that was completed in June. 
In Europe, our U.K. business continues to execute exceptionally well with significant organic revenue growth. Our results also reflect the benefits from the EU interchange regulation that became effective in December 2015. 
Outside of the U.K., Spain maintained its strong track record with yet another quarter of double-digit volume and transaction growth, well in excess of the market rate of growth in Spanish GDP. 
We remain pleased with the performance of our European e-commerce Gateway business, Realex, and we are poised to enter the Spanish markets with new omnichannel offerings in the coming months, following the U.K. launch last fall. 
In the Asia-Pacific region, we produced strong revenue growth on a local currency basis despite ongoing macroeconomic headwinds in Greater China. Our strategy to diversify distribution in the region by entering new geographic markets and partnerships has been successful. Ezidebit had another outstanding quarter accelerating growth to 20% plus on a local currency basis. Our BPI joint venture also continues to perform in line with our expectations. We have been able to offset macro weakness by solid execution illustrated by margin performance in Asia, which significantly exceeded our expectations. 
We are also building upon our successful partnership with Ezidebit with the acquisition of eWay [ph], a payment gateway and e-commerce technology company in Australia. Similar to Realex in our Ireland, eWay is a leading provider of payment solution to developers and software partners with approximately 25% of the online market. The combination of eWay's cutting-edge products with Ezidebit complements our global omnichannel solution strategy and will create the leading payment technology company in Asia-Pacific with nearly 40,000 merchant customers in Australia and New Zealand. 
We have made considerable progress on our pending acquisition of Heartland Payment Systems, which we look to close later this month. This transaction will accelerate transformative growth at a time when both businesses are executing strongly and we continue to be impressed with the people we have met at Heartland. As we have done successfully with APT, PayPros, Ezidebit and Realex, we are confident in our ability to accelerate sales growth at Heartland. 
The goal of our integration is to ensure a frictionless transition postclose, building on the momentum that Global Payments at Heartland's have each had individually as one combined company. We are even more confident in the synergies that we describe at the time of the transaction announcements and could not be more pleased with our proposed partnership. We look forward to welcoming our new colleague shortly. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Cameron.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We've made substantial progress business in fiscal 2016 and are delighted to report another quarter of strong adjusted net revenue growth, operating margin expansion and cash earnings per share growth despite s
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We've made substantial progress business in fiscal 2016 and are delighted to report another quarter of strong adjusted net revenue growth, operating margin expansion and cash earnings per share growth despite significant FX headwinds. 
Total company net revenue for the third quarter was $497 million, reflecting growth of 6% versus the third quarter of fiscal 2015 or 11% on a constant currency basis. Importantly, normalized organic net revenue growth on a constant currency basis was high single digits for the quarter at the high end of our cycle guidance. 
Operating margins expanded 50 basis points to 28.7% for the quarter or 110 basis points on a constant currency basis. Cash earnings per share increased 17% to $0.70 or 28% on a constant currency basis. 
North America net revenue grew 6% in the quarter with operating margin expansion of 70 basis points to 27.2% despite unfavorable currency trends in Canada. Normalized organic net revenue growth in our U.S. direct channels was high single digits for the quarter and accelerated sequentially relative to fiscal second quarter performance. 
Canada delivered solid growth in local currency, in line with expectations, driven by stable fundamentals. The weak Canadian dollar impacted North America net revenue growth by several hundred basis points. 
As Jeff noted, our European business performed exceptionally well, again, this quarter posting revenue growth of 8%. Adjusting for adverse currency exchange rates, especially the British pound in Europe, European constant currency net revenue growth was 16%. Operating margins in Europe for the quarter increased 10 basis points to 49.7%. 
Asia-Pacific net revenue grew 9% on a constant currency basis, despite continued macroeconomic weakness in Greater China. Reported net revenue growth in Asia-Pacific was 3% as a result of significantly unfavorable foreign currency exchange rates. 
We are particularly pleased with operating margins in Asia-Pacific for the quarter, which expanded by over 600 basis points. This was driven primarily by growth in our higher margin businesses, predominantly Ezidebit, as well as expense management across the region in light of the broader macro trends. 
Capital expenditures of the quarter totaled $21 million. Free cash flow, defined as net operating cash flows, excluding settlement assets and obligations, less capital expenditures and distributions to noncontrolling interests, was $77 million. 
In connection with our planned acquisition of Heartland, we have engaged in a variety of financing-related activities over the past few months. In February, we amended our existing credit facilities to repay the post-closing of the Heartland transaction. At the same time, given strong interest from existing and new lenders, we entered into a new $735 million delayed draw Term Loan A facility to fund a portion of the cash consideration for the transaction. The new Term Loan A facility, which we expect to be more cost-effective than our Term Loan B, allowed us to reduce the size of the Term Loan B component of the transaction financing by $735 million to $1.045 billion. In addition, in March, we successfully completed this indication of the $1.045 billion Term Loan B facility on terms and conditions more favorable than we expected in December. 
As a result of these activities we now expect the weighted average pro forma interest rate on our debt facilities to be in the range of 3.75% to 4% as compared to the 4% to 4.25% range we anticipated at the time of the announcement of the transaction. We expect this will generate a meaningful amount of annual interest expense savings relative to our original pro forma assumptions. 
As we approach the closing of the Heartland transaction later this month, we intend to resume more normal capital allocation policies immunity thereafter, although our near-term priority is to return to our targeted leverage ratio we retain sufficient capacity to continue to pursue the capital allocation program we have employed with much success over the past few years. 
As evidenced by the eWay transaction, we remain interested in select acquisitions that augment our strategies globally. Likewise, you should assume that we will return to being a consistent buyer of our stock as a means by which to return capital to shareholders. 
Now turning to our guidance for fiscal 2016. On a constant currency basis, we expect net revenues to be toward the high end of our guidance range of 10% to 12% growth over fiscal 2015. Given the continued weakness we have seen in foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar, in particular, the British pound, we expect reported revenues to be towards the low end of our previous guidance range of $2.06 billion to $2.10 billion. We are increasing our cash operating margin expectations and now anticipate margins will expand by at least 100 basis points in fiscal 2016 on a constant currency basis. Cash earnings per share are now expected to grow 16% to 19% over fiscal 2015 and range from $2.93 to $3.
Finally, please note that our outlook does not include the impact of the Heartland's acquisition that we expect to close later this month. We anticipate that the addition of Heartland will add $80 million to $100 million to our net revenues and has de minimis impact on cash earnings per share for fiscal 2016. 
I will now turn the call back to Jeff.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Cameron. We are delighted with our teams a company's with this quarter and this fiscal year. Looking ahead, we are eager to finalize our transformative partnership with Heartland. This merger furthers the 4 pillars of our strategy described in
componenttext: Thank you, Cameron. We are delighted with our teams a company's with this quarter and this fiscal year. Looking ahead, we are eager to finalize our transformative partnership with Heartland. This merger furthers the 4 pillars of our strategy described in our October Investor Day: Grow and control direct distribution through the addition of 300,000 new merchants; add distinctive products and services in new markets, such as the K-12 and university educational markets; leverage our combined technological and operational advantages by increasing transaction nearly 50% on a pro forma basis; and continue to invest in our global businesses to generate superior returns. This is truly an exciting time and I look forward to speaking with you in July as one combined company. Andrew?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ashwin Shirvaikar of Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ashwin Shirvaikar of Citigroup.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question I have is with regards to the margin trajectory and you would now performed, I guess, better than expected on margins for a couple of years here. I'm wondering how much more is there in terms of margin improvement ex the Heartla
componenttext: I guess the first question I have is with regards to the margin trajectory and you would now performed, I guess, better than expected on margins for a couple of years here. I'm wondering how much more is there in terms of margin improvement ex the Heartland synergies, I mean, maybe if Heartland was not a factor, can you go through, as you look at the company in the present shape, what are the factors that continue to drive the margin improvement, is it primarily scale, revenue mix, still, what are the factors?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ashwin, it's Jeff, I'll start and I'll ask Cameron to join me as well. First, I still think we've got plenty of runway on margin enhancement. I think as we said, probably a number of times in the last couple of years, we view margins on a stand-alone basi
componenttext: Ashwin, it's Jeff, I'll start and I'll ask Cameron to join me as well. First, I still think we've got plenty of runway on margin enhancement. I think as we said, probably a number of times in the last couple of years, we view margins on a stand-alone basis in the low-30s as achievable and sustainable. Even with terrific margin performance today, we're still not at that level. I think to get to your question about what's driving that growth and undoubtedly scale is an important element of that, but I think it's really been a conscious decision on our part to shift our mix toward businesses that we've U.S.A. attractive and by attractive, I mean growth faster than the rate than market growth with better margin characteristics. So if you look, for example, at OpenEdge, which we talked a lot about, it continues to grow as we said in our prepared remarks at rates 2x to 3x the rate of market growth. If you look as Realex, if you look at Ezidebit, these are all businesses that, Ashwin, that, first, are growing fairly rapidly compared to the market, but second, provide us with opportunities for further margin enhancement prior to Heartland. So I still think we're in the early innings of where we can take the margins that gives you obviously comfort as we look toward Heartland to think about what we might do together as one combined company. Cameron?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the only thing I would add to that, a couple of points. First, if you look at our guidance for this year sort of implies almost 30% margin and growth of, as we noted, over 100 basis points year-over-year. We still have a lot of from relative to ov
componenttext: Yes. So the only thing I would add to that, a couple of points. First, if you look at our guidance for this year sort of implies almost 30% margin and growth of, as we noted, over 100 basis points year-over-year. We still have a lot of from relative to overall target level of low-30s to continue to expand margin from here on, on a stand-alone basis. In addition to the items Jeff described, the other things I would call out is specifically are, one, of the acquisitions we continue to do we improve scale end markets that we find attractive that have good dynamics where our business are geared towards higher-margin solutions, such as for example, the eWay transition that we just executed and its contributions to our Australian business and what it will do to margins in Australia to continue to improve those from their already attractive levels. The last thing I would mention is we continue to make investments in our infrastructure to improve our operational leverage. We continue this transformation we started out on several years ago to move away from the holding company, operating company model the business utilized for many years to the single unified operating company structure that David described at the Investor Conference back in October, that's still in process. And I think that continued evolution provides a nice tailwind for margin expansion over time as well.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess and then the follow-up is really on Heartland. Your comments that Heartland -- that the progress you're making on Heartland is better than where you expected to be. Was that primarily Cameron a reflection of your commentary on interest expen
componenttext: Okay. I guess and then the follow-up is really on Heartland. Your comments that Heartland -- that the progress you're making on Heartland is better than where you expected to be. Was that primarily Cameron a reflection of your commentary on interest expense? Or where you also talking about other things, such as conversations with clients, feedback you're receiving in the market, things like that, if you could comment on that?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ashwin, it's Jeff, I'll certainly start. No, it's more on the strategic side. So what I'd say is as we spend more time with our future colleagues at Heartland. We've been more and more impressed with the quality of the people, the quality of the culture o
componenttext: Ashwin, it's Jeff, I'll certainly start. No, it's more on the strategic side. So what I'd say is as we spend more time with our future colleagues at Heartland. We've been more and more impressed with the quality of the people, the quality of the culture of the business that Bob and the team has built over a period of decades at Heartland. I think David has said in the December call that were roughly an overlap between Heartland's vertical markets and our markets even though we're both SME-focused. Our view on that continues to strengthen, meaning there's really little overlap as we see it. And as I said in my prepared remarks, we believe that we're even more confident today an synergies that we describe in December sitting here and not in April. So really, I was repairing to the strategic rationale for the transaction and what we believe the receptiveness is and has been to-date with our partners at Heartland, as well as with potential customers. Cameron, of course, was commenting more on the financials but I like commenting on the strategic objectives.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Ashwin, my comments in the script, around the financings, obviously, certainly serve to bolster the overall competence and the transaction as well, taking the financing risk off the table as we have in the first quarter of calendar '16, obviously
componenttext: Yes, and Ashwin, my comments in the script, around the financings, obviously, certainly serve to bolster the overall competence and the transaction as well, taking the financing risk off the table as we have in the first quarter of calendar '16, obviously, was a meaningful step towards executing the transaction and obviously being able to do that on terms and conditions that a far more favorable than we would've expected back in December when we announced the transaction, again, gives us a nice tailwind as we look to close later this month and begin operating as a combined company in the next several weeks.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bryan Keane of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bryan Keane of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to ask about the U.K. strength, is that directly related to the changes in the EU regulation or is that something different?
componenttext: Just want to ask about the U.K. strength, is that directly related to the changes in the EU regulation or is that something different?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bryan, it's Jeff, I would say it's probably something different meaning we probably had now 18 months of very solid new sales growth, organic sales execution in that market, yet the benefit of the interchange regulation really picked up in December of 201
componenttext: Bryan, it's Jeff, I would say it's probably something different meaning we probably had now 18 months of very solid new sales growth, organic sales execution in that market, yet the benefit of the interchange regulation really picked up in December of 2015. So certainly, the performance in the U.K. I think as we described last quarter in the call has significantly exceeded our expectations, really whole year and probably for the last 18 months so it's a little bit more of that. As it relates to the interchange benefits, as we discussed in context of Spain and also in the case of United States where we had Durbin 4, 5 years ago, we do the interchange benefits a little bit more temporal, that's just a function of over what period of time that the whale rationalize within the marketplace. But that business as it relates to that elements of its growth has also met where our expectations our heading into the third quarter. So it's a little bit more of the latter of what you said in the former.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you expect the EU interchange benefit in the U.K. to last for a significant period or is it hard to tell how long it will last for?
componenttext: And do you expect the EU interchange benefit in the U.K. to last for a significant period or is it hard to tell how long it will last for?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think Bryan it's very similar to what we said about Spain and the United States markets and other markets in which we have experienced it. We tend to think about it in 12 month increments for kind of obvious reasons, as you can imagine. This actuall
componenttext: No, I think Bryan it's very similar to what we said about Spain and the United States markets and other markets in which we have experienced it. We tend to think about it in 12 month increments for kind of obvious reasons, as you can imagine. This actually straddles a number of fiscal years here since it started in the December for us given our May fiscal year. So I'd say Bryan is we usually assume something like 12 to 18 months until we get back to levels that predate the interchange change. Our actually experience has been closer to 18- to 24 months in terms of what we saw in the United States. I say sitting here in Spain and we're probably 18 months after the inception in September of 2014 in Spain, we are still today, Bryan, at higher levels of spread in Spain than we were before the adoption in the first place 18 months layer.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up, Cameron, I think you said $80 million to $100 million in net revenue for Heartland, expectations. I guess, is that over a 4- to 5-week period? And I guess, I'll do is will extrapolate what that means for next year, i
componenttext: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up, Cameron, I think you said $80 million to $100 million in net revenue for Heartland, expectations. I guess, is that over a 4- to 5-week period? And I guess, I'll do is will extrapolate what that means for next year, is there any seasonality in that number that you guys as we build our models for fiscal year '16 and '17?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bryan and, of course, we'll give you more color in July obviously, when we have our call as to what we would anticipate for Heartland for a full fiscal '17, for us. But to the first part of your question, yes, I mean, it reflects sort of 4- to 5-wee
componenttext: Sure, Bryan and, of course, we'll give you more color in July obviously, when we have our call as to what we would anticipate for Heartland for a full fiscal '17, for us. But to the first part of your question, yes, I mean, it reflects sort of 4- to 5-week period. We don't know exactly when it's going to close. Obviously, we know when their shareholder date is and we'll look to close as quickly thereafter as possible, but we don't know the exact date on which it will close, hence the range. There's also obviously, some work to do to ensure that they're completely aligned with our net revenue reporting convention. We believe that the estimate we provided obviously is a line, but we need to get under the hood a little bit further to make sure that's the case as well. Their business is probably going to be seasonally similar to ours. So to the extent that you want to try to extrapolate these numbers into a fiscal '17 early view, I would suggest those seasonality is not going to be materially different than what you would see in our business and that should help give you some color as to how to shape it for fiscal '17.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, George, this is David, happy to have a couple of those questions there, I'll let Cameron add details that I missed. In terms of the ISO channel, it's really business as usual for us. It was another flat quarter from a revenue perspective, that means
componenttext: Yes, George, this is David, happy to have a couple of those questions there, I'll let Cameron add details that I missed. In terms of the ISO channel, it's really business as usual for us. It was another flat quarter from a revenue perspective, that means all the growth that Cameron's talking about, the acceleration comes from our direct control channels, so another very consistent quarter. We've been talking about the ISO for quite some time as a flat maybe low single-digit grower. It continues to perform in that range. As to the migration you're talking about, maybe I'll be even more specific, appreciate though the way you phrased your question. You're really talking about Mercury and the migration of the Mercury accounts that will leaving us did actually occur over the course of this past quarter. So by the end of our February, the month of February, our third quarter, the migrations were completed. And we talk as we talk about any number of times, that impact is already perfect an independent you can tell from the performance we deliver innovative state this quarter just how minor this migration is in terms of affecting Global Payments overall.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cameron, I'll just add a couple of comments here quickly as to the first part of your question. U.S. direct growth on a normalized basis, organic was high single-digits for the quarter, accelerating sequentially over Q2, probably 50 to 100 basis points, s
componenttext: Cameron, I'll just add a couple of comments here quickly as to the first part of your question. U.S. direct growth on a normalized basis, organic was high single-digits for the quarter, accelerating sequentially over Q2, probably 50 to 100 basis points, something in that range. So obviously, very pleased. That continues to be led by OpenEdge, growing mid to high teens yet, again. Obviously, we're now 3 years past the acquisition of APT and going on 2 for PayPros and continuing to perform again at growth levels that we find very, very attractive and the momentum were made strong for that business. So very pleased with our U.S. performance in Q3 as you noted.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great to hear. And just a quick follow-up on Spain. I think you guys made the commentary, the spreads are obviously higher than what they were prior to the interchange benefit coming through, but have the spread stabilized on a quarter-over-quarter
componenttext: That's great to hear. And just a quick follow-up on Spain. I think you guys made the commentary, the spreads are obviously higher than what they were prior to the interchange benefit coming through, but have the spread stabilized on a quarter-over-quarter basis compare the February quarter to the November quarter?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, George, they have stabilized. They stabilized just above levels, as Jeff noted, before the interchange benefits, but they are quite stable right now. And then I think I'd add to that what's really driving Spain is incredible sales growth, incredible
componenttext: Yes, George, they have stabilized. They stabilized just above levels, as Jeff noted, before the interchange benefits, but they are quite stable right now. And then I think I'd add to that what's really driving Spain is incredible sales growth, incredible volume growth that continues in the mid-teens volume and transaction growth, both. So we've got a little extra spread from the back in the day, plus that kind of volume and transaction growth. We're just in a great place in Spain right now.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Oscar Turner [ph] from SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Oscar Turner [ph] from SunTrust.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've seen some news on the backlog for EMB certifications, so just had a couple of questions on that. One is this something you're seeing within your merchant base? And two, does this have any long-term implications for acquirers?
componenttext: So we've seen some news on the backlog for EMB certifications, so just had a couple of questions on that. One is this something you're seeing within your merchant base? And two, does this have any long-term implications for acquirers?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Oscar it's Jeff, I'll start and then David can provide some commentary, too. So first, I saw the same series of article. The first thing I'd say relative to those articles is unlike some of our peers, we're independent bank. So clearly, the implicati
componenttext: Yes, Oscar it's Jeff, I'll start and then David can provide some commentary, too. So first, I saw the same series of article. The first thing I'd say relative to those articles is unlike some of our peers, we're independent bank. So clearly, the implication of that article was that there were some relationship between bank ownership on the issuing side on the acquiring side and just so we all recognize that, that that wouldn't really not apply to us as it relates to the specific article I think you're referring to. As it relates to the certifications, I think the key strength of ours has been early rollout of the EMB we announced probably 1 year ago, at this point maybe a little bit more than 1 year ago as suite of products and services under the names of EdgeShield and GlobalShield that were EMV compliant with encryption and tokenization and NFC kind of all wrapped into one. So I think everybody has had to push on the certification side given the complexity of the U.S. broader ecosystem, so I don't think that that's different really for anyone. But I would say that we're very proud of the fact that we were in market and Heartland was probably very similar in market very early on with the certifications. So we really, on our side, have not seen any meaningful impact as it relates to the certifications. The way that article really had alluded to as I read it. David, you want to [indiscernible]

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I think, the key is the last couple things you mentioned Jeff is that we don't feel EMV as a compliance exercise. As part of a security solution we're bringing to market based on merchant demand. At the same time, we also bring to market what i
componenttext: Yes, well, I think, the key is the last couple things you mentioned Jeff is that we don't feel EMV as a compliance exercise. As part of a security solution we're bringing to market based on merchant demand. At the same time, we also bring to market what is global expertise in EMV, we've rolled out EMV all over the world. As you might imagine, all the way back to Canada 5 years ago is probably the most recent example of needing to bring EMV to market to improve security for the merchants. When you think about the focus on security suites and solutions, we've been able to drive some new sales around security, but EMV, itself, is in no way an economic tailwind for us. It's a process for us in terms of migration of making sure the ecosystem is more secure. From that perspective, from an ecosystem perspective, our metrics are really right in line with what you might see from the industry at large, measured migration, consistent migration is our theme, driven by merchant demand after merchant education from Global Payments. One thing I would note for you though is when you think about our key direct portfolios things like OpenEdge, which is full of dentis offices, veterinary clinics, dry cleaners, those are not high demand verticals for EMV migration. So we're working with the pace our merchants want to work, we're trying to drive more education, drive more migration. As Jeff noted before, certifications are in very good shape. We're just moving along with the market, in some cases a little ahead of the market. One more reminder in terms of percentage when you see them banded about by industry payers, we have a very focused portfolio at this Heartland on small to medium merchants around the country. You won't find big-box retailers in our portfolio. You won't find them by and large at Heartland's portfolio either. So just remember that when we talk about the level of migration and the pace. We've got a lot of small to medium merchants to go through as so the rest of the industry. We're going through them very consistently. Very happy with the progress, I think our merchants are as well. We're managing charge with the merchants, which is maybe a follow-up you might want to ask. In terms if there's a minor uptick, but very manageable so far. And I think again, that's the results of years of global experience managing EMV, managing the shift and being able to help our margin through it.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a small follow-up to that. About what percentage of your merchant base is not updated for EMV, so either that's upgraded as far as hardware goes or that's able to actually process an EMV transaction?
componenttext: Okay. And just a small follow-up to that. About what percentage of your merchant base is not updated for EMV, so either that's upgraded as far as hardware goes or that's able to actually process an EMV transaction?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't we're going to quote any specific percentage. I would stick with we are very consistent with the industry stat you see yet at large. We're very happy with the progress. And I think our margins again are driving it from a demand perspective. B
componenttext: Yes, I don't we're going to quote any specific percentage. I would stick with we are very consistent with the industry stat you see yet at large. We're very happy with the progress. And I think our margins again are driving it from a demand perspective. But just know that whether you're talking about terminals in place that are ready to be enabled or actually enabled transactions, we're pretty consistent. And our key verticals maybe a little bit ahead of the market and the industry said it's about 20%, that obviously includes an awful lot of big box retailers because there's been a great deal of movement in the last few months from very low single-digits up to that 20 percentage kind of mark you've seen in the press in the last couple of weeks, that's a lot of big-box retail, but it's really nice progress with the industry. I think we'll keep making more progress on the global side obviously as we go forward.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oscar, it's Cameron, I just want to add one other note to append to David's response. If you're thinking about this question obviously, there's an industry element to it but there maybe a financial element as well. There seems to be a fair amount of confu
componenttext: Oscar, it's Cameron, I just want to add one other note to append to David's response. If you're thinking about this question obviously, there's an industry element to it but there maybe a financial element as well. There seems to be a fair amount of confusion in the market as it relates to the financial impact of EMV and some of that is driven by in the space and there's a lot of issuers who also do acquiring, et cetera, et cetera. I think for Global Payments, in particular, EMV is not certainly not been tailwind as it relates to our financial results. I think I still view it frankly and when it is estimated to make investments into our systems and I'm still waiting for the return on that investment to some degree. Over time, obviously, I think we expect that to come but to David's point, our focus has really been heretofore to ensuring that our merchants have all the tools available to them to become compliant, working at a pace that aligns with their desires to become EMV compliant. We haven't really viewed it as an economic return opportunity thus afar. So the conventional wisdom is EMV has been a tailwind for all the acquirers, that's really not the case for us, but we have been I think managing through it very, very effectively.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Kwok of KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steven Kwok of KBW.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to eWay, can you talk about how big it is and in terms of what the financial impacts are?
componenttext: Just going back to eWay, can you talk about how big it is and in terms of what the financial impacts are?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, it's Cameron. I'll just jump in quickly. So purchase price-wise, it's small. I mean, it's sort of USD 50-ish million. So it's not a particularly large asset, but it's a very nice, I think of it as a product add to our existing position in Ezidebit
componenttext: Steven, it's Cameron. I'll just jump in quickly. So purchase price-wise, it's small. I mean, it's sort of USD 50-ish million. So it's not a particularly large asset, but it's a very nice, I think of it as a product add to our existing position in Ezidebit business in Australia. It obviously enhances our omni solution, omnichannel solution strategy that we spoke at great length about in October at our Investor Day. I think bringing that asset to our portfolio into Australia really positions us to accelerate our omnichannel solutions capability in market. And we really looked at it very simply as a buy versus bulk opportunity. We're delighted with Realex and what it's been able to bring to our portfolio. As we noted in our prepared comments, we lost the bundle in the fall in the U.K. We're bringing it to Spain in the not-too-distant future. But as it related to Australia, this was a very unique opportunity to buy the market leader from an e-com point of view, couple it with our existing presence with Ezidebit, which we've been thrilled with their performance to create the leading technology-enabled distribution platform in the Asia-Pacific region. So with a fantastic opportunity. And one of the side benefits of the structuring the Heartland transaction the way we do is we've maintained the financial capacity to be able to do these types of things. And we're obviously delighted to have eWay as part of the family.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just can you update us on perhaps your M&A pipeline as well?
componenttext: Got it. And just can you update us on perhaps your M&A pipeline as well?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steven, it's Jeff, I'll respond to that. So obviously, we announced a product extension today with eWay. As we said in December, at the time of the Heartland announcement, we continue to have term sheet out in a bunch of regions, primarily in Asia a
componenttext: Sure, Steven, it's Jeff, I'll respond to that. So obviously, we announced a product extension today with eWay. As we said in December, at the time of the Heartland announcement, we continue to have term sheet out in a bunch of regions, primarily in Asia and in Europe, of course, we're pretty full up here in the United States and in North America with the pending close of the Heartland transaction. As I think if you look at eWay, and as you look at Ersa [ph], which we expect to close by the end of this fiscal year, I think to Cameron's point, those are pretty good examples of the types of transactions that we have sheets out on today, which is to say whilst we're at the lower end of what was invested in transactions nonetheless very meaningful from a strategic and new market point of view. And I would look to see some more of those, as well as Cameron mentioned in his remarks, a return to the normal cadence of capital allocation that we've been doing as a company over the last 3.5 years.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tien-tsin Huang from JPMorgan.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to first start on Asia Pac, I guess, the margins there, nice upside. How much of this is from the proactive cost cutting, I think you mentioned given I think, China? How much of impact have you seen from a macro perspective from China? Can you quan
componenttext: I want to first start on Asia Pac, I guess, the margins there, nice upside. How much of this is from the proactive cost cutting, I think you mentioned given I think, China? How much of impact have you seen from a macro perspective from China? Can you quantify some of that?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Tien-tsin, it's Jeff, I'll start. So one of the things that we pointed out in our prepared remarks is we've been very successful in Asia-Pacific by adding new markets and by increasing our presence in markets that have been performing well. So we ta
componenttext: Sure, Tien-tsin, it's Jeff, I'll start. So one of the things that we pointed out in our prepared remarks is we've been very successful in Asia-Pacific by adding new markets and by increasing our presence in markets that have been performing well. So we talk a lot about Australia, we just responded to Steven talking about eWay and Ezidebit. Of course, we have our joint a venture with Bank of the Philippine Islands, which were also performing in line with our expectations in that market before the JV and we increased our size to the second largest presence in that market thereafter. As a result, we've been able to grow, to answer your question, we've been able to grow the Asian Pacific business 9% on a constant currency basis this quarter. So I'd say, we're still getting very good growth in Greater China, which I define as mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Macau as a percentage of the business in Asia-Pacific has been reduced from probably, a number of years ago, probably about half of it, so maybe around 30% currently and that largely a result of targeted additions in other markets like Australia, New Zealand and the Philippines. We also continue to grow very well in markets like Singapore beyond the 2 or 3 that I just listed. So I would say there's been a fair amount of revenue growth it seems about 2/3 of Asia-Pacific, Tien-tsin, coming from markets other than as a percentage of revenue other than Greater China providing, in the case of Ezidebit, 20% plus growth. It's not like we're going to have a dramatic impact on the revenue growth in any one quarter, Greater China, that is. So I think a lot of it is coming from the mix of business, particularly that Ezidebit is a much higher margin than the overall company, as well as Asia, by itself. And that's how I think about it. Cameron, you can comment maybe a little bit on the expense side.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll just start maybe Tien-tsin on Easy. So I would note, first and foremost, we're 1 year plus beyond the acquisition. We now, I think, in our minds, fully integrated Ezidebit so that is creating an environment where incremental margins at Ezi are
componenttext: Sure. I'll just start maybe Tien-tsin on Easy. So I would note, first and foremost, we're 1 year plus beyond the acquisition. We now, I think, in our minds, fully integrated Ezidebit so that is creating an environment where incremental margins at Ezi are improving and obviously it's already higher than our Asia average margins, and so it's increasing from there and accelerating from there. So I think that's contributing to it. But as it relates to the expense side, I think what we really try to do is look at our core business in Asia-Pacific outside of Australia and to some degree the Philippines where we have the joint venture with BPI and really try to rationalize the size of the expense base relative to the outlook for that market over the next 12 to 18 months. And the reality is we do expect continued weakness in China, hopefully, we've seen before, but we don't expect it to rebound dramatically in the near term. So we really try to reposition the business to ride out what we expect to be a soft spot in the cycle in the Greater China markets and position the business for continued success. And I think you're seeing the results of that play through in margins this quarter.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good, that's helpful. So just with my follow-up, I think I'll ask on Canada. Just any update on volume and spread performance? Any call-outs there, I think, we're all watching the macro very closely?
componenttext: Good, that's helpful. So just with my follow-up, I think I'll ask on Canada. Just any update on volume and spread performance? Any call-outs there, I think, we're all watching the macro very closely?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think I'll start by saying that we're delighted with the performance of our Canadian team this year. their ability to forecast, predict and manage their business to produce results in line with our expectations, in light of what is obviously a cont
componenttext: Yes, I think I'll start by saying that we're delighted with the performance of our Canadian team this year. their ability to forecast, predict and manage their business to produce results in line with our expectations, in light of what is obviously a continued soft macroeconomic environment, has been fantastic. So I'll start there. I think we continue to see sort of our code for stable fundamentals is a combination of stable low single-digit transaction volume growth and relatively stable spreads. So when we talk about fundamentals for Canada, our expectation is the combination of transaction volume growth and stable spread is going to produce low single-digit growth in local currency in that market. We've been consistently doing that now for probably 8 to 10 quarters, I would say, and I remained very pleased with how the team is performing light of the broader macro issues.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe Tien-tsin, this is David, a little commercial for Canada, we're ahead on sales. So when you lay on top of that sales growth and new product introductions, things like OptBlue that we've rolled out on a global basis, you got that little bit extra
componenttext: And maybe Tien-tsin, this is David, a little commercial for Canada, we're ahead on sales. So when you lay on top of that sales growth and new product introductions, things like OptBlue that we've rolled out on a global basis, you got that little bit extra to make you feel more confident in managing those stable conditions and the stable metrics that Cameron was describing.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Dave Koning of R.W. Baird.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Dave Koning of R.W. Baird.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice job. And I guess, first of all, just on the Spain, I'm wondering if that could be in nice catalyst for growth or improving growth into next year. I know you spreads are still up, but is revenue right now down because the spreads on a year-over-year b
componenttext: Nice job. And I guess, first of all, just on the Spain, I'm wondering if that could be in nice catalyst for growth or improving growth into next year. I know you spreads are still up, but is revenue right now down because the spreads on a year-over-year basis are probably still down and the minority interest line was pretty weak this quarter. So I'm just wondering, if Spain right now is even though good in a little tougher spot, but basically set to really nice and accelerate out next year?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, it's David. I think that's a really pressing question. And that where right now is flat to slightly up in terms of revenue growth, which is really remarkable when you think about annualizing that interchange benefit and it's, of course, driven
componenttext: Yes, David, it's David. I think that's a really pressing question. And that where right now is flat to slightly up in terms of revenue growth, which is really remarkable when you think about annualizing that interchange benefit and it's, of course, driven by the amazing sales we get out of the branches and the results and volume transaction growth in the mid-teens. So you're exactly right, as we look ahead and can think through fully annualizing spread changes, et cetera, as we head toward September, it is accelerating as we speak in terms of market share and penetration and it will be a piece of the European growth story that Cameron was describing earlier as we go forward, no question about it.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And David, it's Cameron, the only thing I'll add to David's point more specifically, we annualized the annualization of the interchange reductions in September. So when you're growing transaction and volumes at the rate we're growing, once you get beyond
componenttext: And David, it's Cameron, the only thing I'll add to David's point more specifically, we annualized the annualization of the interchange reductions in September. So when you're growing transaction and volumes at the rate we're growing, once you get beyond that date, obviously, you should see top line growing at similar levels, which creates a nice tailwind growing into the back half of fiscal '17 in Europe as we start to annualize the interchange reductions in the U.K.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that all makes sense. Great. And I guess secondly, as we look out -- next quarter, you'll be giving guidance on fiscal '17 and we'll be all looking at Heartland and everything else going on, but is there anything, as we look back over the last year o
componenttext: Yes, that all makes sense. Great. And I guess secondly, as we look out -- next quarter, you'll be giving guidance on fiscal '17 and we'll be all looking at Heartland and everything else going on, but is there anything, as we look back over the last year or so, is there anything we need to think about from a top standpoint so that we're starting to think about the quarters right in the future? Is like the Q1 comp for Q1 '17 a really tough one? Or is there anything one-off that we need to be starting to think about now?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think your point on Q1 is a good one. As we said in October, when we had our first quarter call, Q1 was an exceptional quarter this year and not one that we expect to duplicate, notwithstanding that there seem to be sort of a view that we would duplicat
componenttext: I think your point on Q1 is a good one. As we said in October, when we had our first quarter call, Q1 was an exceptional quarter this year and not one that we expect to duplicate, notwithstanding that there seem to be sort of a view that we would duplicate it in Q2 despite having a very good quarter it wasn't quite as good as Q1. So I do think that's a fair point as you think about sort of setting your model up for fiscal '17. Outside of that, it's just again and I talked to many of you guys about this is it's sort of assessing the FX impact on results and trying to figure out how to overlay those on top of annualization of acquisition of that we've made and how all that plays through the financials. Obviously, happy to talk more offline as I think about that. But obviously, the volatility around the FX and the amount of headwind we've seen from FX does make it a little bit difficult from time to time to try to get reported results forecasted correctly quarter-over-quarter, year-over-year.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say Dave, though, it's Jeff, that's exactly right. I would say is a company, as you know, from our descriptions before, is going to go about half the revenue being in the United States and half outside the dollar-denominated into 2/3 post Heartlan
componenttext: I would say Dave, though, it's Jeff, that's exactly right. I would say is a company, as you know, from our descriptions before, is going to go about half the revenue being in the United States and half outside the dollar-denominated into 2/3 post Heartland dollar-denominated. So while Cameron is exactly right in our 3 regions and so regionally, I would hope and complicate Cameron saying, I would hope easier to model coming out just given the mix of 50% dollar-denominated to the overall company going to 2/3. So my hope is that while those things are exactly right that in terms of the impact as a whole on overall company revenue or company earnings base, I've got to hope that's a little more straightforward, but as Cameron said, the devil's in the details and I'm sure we'll get that.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Willi with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tim Willi with Wells Fargo.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on just sort of the e-commerce omnichannel, obviously, you've talked a lot about this in the last year. So given the success in the U.K. and you talked about moving this into Spain, could you maybe sort of review like lessons learned, what has
componenttext: A question on just sort of the e-commerce omnichannel, obviously, you've talked a lot about this in the last year. So given the success in the U.K. and you talked about moving this into Spain, could you maybe sort of review like lessons learned, what has worked really, really well that you think is very exportable into other regions and may be areas where either it's competition or product where areas that needed to be improved and you've probably done that, but maybe hindered in some of the performance if there instances of that get a better feel for the momentum and the potential here?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, this is David. A couple of lessons learned, we're finding very strong demand for the bundled solution in the U.K. The place where we're working the hardest is probably on the joint sales proposition and being able to take what you might think of as a
componenttext: Tim, this is David. A couple of lessons learned, we're finding very strong demand for the bundled solution in the U.K. The place where we're working the hardest is probably on the joint sales proposition and being able to take what you might think of as a traditional sale and marry to it a more technology-enabled piece of the sale. So the gateway married to the acquiring, married to the reporting, married to the fraud and credit management you have to be able to provide. All those tools are there, probably the place where we've learned the more lessons more has been on making those joint sales calls and enabling and equipping traditional sales folks to be able to sell either the early stages of e-commerce enablement to small to medium merchant or sell the entire bundle. The good news is with the demand the demand we've had and the low of execution we've seen, it has not affected our sales trajectory. In fact, we're very pleased with the sales coming out in the back of the demand, but it is a more technical sale. So being able to equip your salespeople on a global basis to sell more technology enabled transaction processing is a challenge of its own. We feel like we've learned a lot in that early integration between the U.K. and the Ireland that will serve us well in Spain particularly. Its allowed us, Tim, to think more specifically about how you target a market and how you focus a piece of the sales force on the macro payments themselves on micro merchants, a piece of the sales force on small to medium and then joint calling of experts maybe from Ireland in addition to Spain on large to national merchants and certainly joint calling between all of your regions, as well as your technical experts in a place Ireland where Realex is based on multiregional or multi-market or regional accounts. So really how you go-to-market has been where you learn lessons. And again, we're fortunate enough to be learning them in a situation where the sales are right at target or above in many cases, so we feel good about those pieces. If you step back a little bit and think about this, the second pieces -- the second and third pieces of this is really partners and software developers. As you enter new markets, you want to continue the momentum you have with channel partners, so ISVs, card providers, folks like that. You also want to develop and foster relationship with developers, the press to shops of this world when you've seen the press even from other providers and e-commerce world. So in specific markets, you've got certain ISVs, card providers, as well as software providers. You're also taking a regional partners with you. So being able to go-to-market and manage the direct sales as I described earlier in a specific region, the face-to-face married to technology, as well as the local channel partners, local software providers and with that an overlay of the regional folks and, in many cases, the global software providers, it's a little tricky and it comes down again to market segmentation and how you compensate and drive the direct sales force to certain behaviors you want to target the segments, make sure they don't trip over each other and make sure that you can drive joint sales. That's all a bit financial global we're really pretty please with the pieces, so pleased that we went ahead and deployed $50 million of more capital in Australia to continue executing the same strategy where we can take this bundle with Ezidebit and eWay to market and drive deeper penetration already the leading provider of small- to medium-sized retail e-commerce in Australia. So long-winded answer, I realize, but it's actually been a great deal of learning, a great deal of really excellent execution by our teams in Ireland, in the U.K. and now about to be in Spain, this led us to sort of feel pretty good about the execution levels we're seeking credited something we spent a lot of time describing at the Investor Day in October, omnichannel, global capabilities that we think we are uniquely positioned to sell.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh of Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kevin McVeigh of Macquarie.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cameron, can you give us a sense of there's been obviously so much FX pressure, you feel like we're starting to anniversary that and maybe think about any kind of relief as we think about '16 into 17? And just any particular thoughts on the noise coming o
componenttext: Cameron, can you give us a sense of there's been obviously so much FX pressure, you feel like we're starting to anniversary that and maybe think about any kind of relief as we think about '16 into 17? And just any particular thoughts on the noise coming out U.K. as well around potential exits just as it relates to currencies as well?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question, Kevin. I would say we're still seeing some weakness in certain markets, particularly the pound and today is another example. I would point to say not only is the U.S. dollar sort of secularly strong, the volatility in some of these
componenttext: It's a great question, Kevin. I would say we're still seeing some weakness in certain markets, particularly the pound and today is another example. I would point to say not only is the U.S. dollar sort of secularly strong, the volatility in some of these major currencies is outstanding. You see pound moving 1.5 point or 2 points intraday, for example, obviously makes a very difficult to forecast FX with any sort of certainty as we think and as we look forward. I think we are as we get into fiscal '17, particularly as we get into the back half of fiscal 17, hopefully we're going to be in a environment where we're starting to anniversary some of the stronger headwinds. But I certainly don't do think that we're approaching anytime soon an environment where the U.S. dollars going to weaken relative to most of the major currencies around the world to which we have exposure. I think we're in a sort of secular bull market for the U.S. dollar. I expect to continue for some time. There's just not a lot out there that would cause me to believe the dollar is going to weaken. But as we continue to anniversary some of these bigger moves, for example, we anniversary the strong euro move in Q3 of this year unfortunately, that was more than offset by an equally strong move downward in the pound at relatively the same time. So we have good exposure to a fair number of currencies. To Jeff's earlier point, part of the benefit of the Heartland transaction is that it does derisk currency exposure to the company on a macro basis, we'll be 2/3 U.. a dollar denominated business going forward and that obviously will diminish some of the FX exposure that we have globally. But I'm hopeful to get into an environment we're in '17, we're leasing most of the strong headwinds begin to diminish to some degree.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from the line of Jason Kupferberg with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our last question comes from the line of Jason Kupferberg with Jefferies.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to just ask a question regarding plans for the Heartland sales force, if we just think about retention, integration, et cetera, any latest thinking there?
componenttext: Wanted to just ask a question regarding plans for the Heartland sales force, if we just think about retention, integration, et cetera, any latest thinking there?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I think the thinking is very similar to what we described to you in December, that's a large part of why we're so attracted to the Heartland acquisition, that sales force, its trajectory has been remarkable the last couple of years. The deeper we'v
componenttext: David, I think the thinking is very similar to what we described to you in December, that's a large part of why we're so attracted to the Heartland acquisition, that sales force, its trajectory has been remarkable the last couple of years. The deeper we've been gone into our homework into the integration, the happier we are with what be found. So our plans are really very similar to into December. We don't want to screw this up, so we're going to keep the performance plans consistent. We're going to keep the bills of rights, which you're familiar and keep using to drive organic growth. As a management matter, we're impressed with the team. We spent a lot more time with them. So I think not a lot of changes at all as you might imagine going forward. And their trajectory right now is really impressive. So it's more a matter of making sure we can figure out how to accelerate that with more product, maybe a different way to think about enhancing the traditional distribution with again, additional product out of Heartland commerce and the other business units that's are already in place there, so really pleased with the pieces, really pleased with the sales force and the trajectory and no plans to change anything we described to you December.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add Jason, it's Cameron, when you think about our entire approach to integration, it's really behind the sales force, behind the customer, such that the objective is to not disrupt anything that's happening from a sales and sales mo
componenttext: The only thing I would add Jason, it's Cameron, when you think about our entire approach to integration, it's really behind the sales force, behind the customer, such that the objective is to not disrupt anything that's happening from a sales and sales momentum point of view nor to create conflict that the customer level that's going to distract the sales professionals from continuing to grow and expand the business. Our objective is to accelerate growth through that channel as we've been able to do with many of the previous acquisitions we've done. And the integration that we're going to do will be behind the scenes such that it won't impact the momentum that we're expecting to be able to achieve from an organic sales point of view.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just to switch gears a little bit to the OpenEdge business, at our payments conference yesterday, there was a lot of positive commentary just about the amount of runway that remains for this channel. So I just wanted to get your unders
componenttext: That's helpful. And just to switch gears a little bit to the OpenEdge business, at our payments conference yesterday, there was a lot of positive commentary just about the amount of runway that remains for this channel. So I just wanted to get your understanding from a global's perspective as far as which verticals you're most excited about, in terms of remaining runway, any updates on the size or growth of the dealer and developer network there?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 06, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, it's David, I'll start and let these guys chime in with anything I missed. So we continue to be very pleased with OpenEdge. Still grows in the mid- to high-teens. The revenue production is really, really impressive. That's all at increasing ma
componenttext: Yes, Jason, it's David, I'll start and let these guys chime in with anything I missed. So we continue to be very pleased with OpenEdge. Still grows in the mid- to high-teens. The revenue production is really, really impressive. That's all at increasing margins that are higher than the company's margin, so back to several other questions earlier today. In terms of the existing verticals, we remain very, very low penetrated, so that's not perfect grammar. But really, I don't think we have a vertical that's more than 20% penetrated anywhere in any of our key verticals. So you think invest, we talk about those a lot, pharma, we think about parking garages, all those very low levels we've got a sales force that's focused on driving deeper penetration into those verticals. At the same time though, we're looking for other places to grow. So we mentioned the Heartland description before we don't have an education vertical in OpenEdge, we don't do restaurant and hospitality the opportunity to drive deeper penetration of those verticals by OpenEdge to complement the direct sales force about what you asked in your first question, it's there, it's real we continue to work on that in integration planning. The other couple of things we have is we literally entered a new vertical in the United States that we weren't in before just in the last couple of weeks. We entered the unattended payment vertical in the United States with a brand-new partner, large ISC who plays in that space, you're talking about car washes, more parking, vending, things like that, that's new and unique for OpenEdge, sort of brand new vertical, effectively worth 0% penetration of that vertical as we sit here today, but we know how to manage the ecosystem  of partners, merchants, leads and marketing to drive that. And then maybe, happiest news of all in terms of how we think about growing that OpenEdge beyond just the United States, the global opportunity is real. We're really pleased we actually have opened up OpenEdge and launched it in the U.K. this quarter, so we have a staff there, dedicated sales folks, dedicated product folks. Remember, back to October, in the Investor Day, one of our key pillars of accelerating global growth was the global expansion of integrated payments, OpenEdge, driving the Canada, driving United Kingdom. So we've now launched our business in the U.K. We can bring that dedicated and product and ecosystem to the United Kingdom to work with ISV to drive the benefits of technology integration that don't exist of the U.K. as they exist in the U.S. today. And best still, we can drive existing partners into the United Kingdom. So U.S.-based ISVs and software providers provide near-term sales opportunities. In fact, we're going to bring a few customers live in the U.K. in just the next few months coming from U.S.-based ISVs where we're extending their franchise, extending the integrated payments benefit out to the U.K. for them. So more to come on this, but really, OpenEdge is poised for more global growth but still continued excellent execution in the United States as we go forward.
