Please go ahead.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Global Payments' Fiscal 2016 Year-End Conference Call. Our call today is scheduled for 1 hour and joining me on the call are Jeff Sloan, CEO; David Mangum, President and COO; and Cameron Bready, Executive Vice President and CF
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Global Payments' Fiscal 2016 Year-End Conference Call. Our call today is scheduled for 1 hour and joining me on the call are Jeff Sloan, CEO; David Mangum, President and COO; and Cameron Bready, Executive Vice President and CFO. 
Before we began, I'd like to remind you that some of the comments made by management during today's conference call contains forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties discussed in our SEC filings, including our most recent 10-K and subsequent filings. These risks and uncertainties could cause actual results to differ materially and we caution you not to place undue reliance on these statements. Forward-looking statements made during this call speak only as of the date of this call and we undertake no obligation to update them.
In addition, some of the comments made on this call may refer to certain measures, such as cash earnings, adjusted net revenue and free cash flow, which are non-GAAP measures. For a full reconciliation of cash earnings, adjusted net revenue to GAAP results in accordance with Regulation G, please see our press release furnished as an exhibit to our Form 8-K filed this morning and our financial highlights, both of which are available in the Investor Relations area of our website at www.globalpaymentsinc.com. 
Now I'd like to introduce Jeff Sloan. Jeff?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew, and thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning. We are delighted with our strong performance in fiscal 2016 highlighting another year of solid execution that generated significant growth across our markets. We also made substantial p
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew, and thanks, everyone, for joining us this morning. We are delighted with our strong performance in fiscal 2016 highlighting another year of solid execution that generated significant growth across our markets. We also made substantial progress in our strategic objectives, including the successful completion of our merger with Heartland in April, a landmark transaction for Global Payments.
For the year, we delivered net revenue growth of 11%, increased operating margin 50 basis points and grew cash earnings per share 18%. Each of these results exceeded our fiscal 2016 budget expectations as well as the cycle guidance we set forth at our Investor Day last October. We are most proud of our ability to accelerate net revenue growth and maintain a consistent level of operating margin expansion and cash EPS growth versus last fiscal, notwithstanding the incremental impacts of foreign currency. 
We expect continued positive momentum in fiscal 2017 as we expand direct distribution, deliver innovative products globally, leverage our technology and operating environments and prudently deploy capital. And, of course, our partnership with Heartland is at the core of this strategy. 
We are very pleased with early results at Heartland. Our combined senior management team is in place and has hit the ground running. New sales at Heartland have set internal records over the last 3 months we've begun to see the anticipated benefits of revenue enhancements across our businesses. We closed our first global cross-sell in June and jointly closed Heartland's largest ever new sale when we signed a major U.S. national restaurant customer in May.
We are already executing initiatives to accelerate revenue growth by enabling sales of our Heartland Campus Solutions, School Solutions and Commerce, point-of-sales payment technology globally as we head into fiscal and calendar 2017. 
Since the closing of the merger on April 22, we have also focused on executing our integration planes, which are critical to the realization of expense synergies. We have successfully completed the first 90-day actions, which consisted of substantial reductions in force facility closures, vendor rationalization and duplicate expense elimination. We are well down the path toward realizing the expense synergies we outlined for fiscal 2017 and beyond. 
And we have not been busy just with Heartland during fiscal 2016. We continue to make progress on the 2 key strategic initiatives to accelerate transformative growth that we described during our Investor Day. International expansion of our OpenEdge, integrated solutions business and continued development of our omnichannel solutions offerings. 
For OpenEdge, we are now lives and driving sales of our solutions to outside of the United States. We recently signed a contract with one of our largest existing ISPs to deliver integrated solutions to their customers in the United Kingdom. We are also pleased with our progress in Canada where we now have 30 ISB bar [ph] partners. We will shortly launch OpenEdge marketing campaigns with both local and U.S.-based partners to further accelerate penetration of our integrated solutions market. 
Our omnichannel solutions businesses had another very good year in fiscal 2016. We added over 4,000 new e-commerce customers in the U.K. and Ireland and signed several enterprise e-commerce clients in the U.K. in the fourth quarter based on the strength of our realized platform. Its scalability, reliability and performance. 
We are well positioned to accelerate growth and we expect to rollout out bundled e-commerce solution in Spain imminently. In addition, we plan to integrate Heartland to e-commerce offering in the United States with our global e-commerce solutions to create best-of-breed omnichannel capabilities before the end of calendar 2016. Furthermore, activation of eWAY also expands the scope of our offerings in the Asia-Pacific region providing us with global reach that is unmatched in our industry. 
Now for quarterly highlights. Our North American business has again delivered strong results. Our U.S. direct channel has generated high single-digit organic revenue growth led by OpenEdge. Canada continued its steady performance in local currency resulting from strong new sales, terrific execution and stable business fundamentals. 
Our European business has again generated solid results. We saw double-digit volume and transaction growth in Spain for the fifth consecutive quarter, well in excess of market price. Outside of Spain, our businesses in the U.K. and Continental Europe performed in line with our expectations. 
While we were disappointed with the result of the recent U.K. EU referendum, we have been preparing for that potential outcome for some time. We had contingency plans in place, which were executed immediately after the result. We do not expect any material impact on operations or earnings expectations as a consequence. We continue to monitor the impact of the referendum and we'll take further actions as conditions warrant. It is also worth noting that our U.S. business is now 2/3 of our net revenue post Heartland with the U.K. now representing single digits of our company's net revenue. 
Asia delivered high single-digit organic net revenue growth in local currency. Much like last quarter, we also generated substantial operating margin expansion as we reacted quickly last fall to emerging macro headwinds in Greater China markets. 
Finally, we remain delighted with our Ezidebit business, which reported accelerated revenue growth above 20% on a local currency basis. Our investment in the eWAY partnership in April highlights the confidence we have in our Australian colleagues and our optimism for this market.
Finally, a word about the change to our fiscal year that we announced today. Last July, we began the journey to provide enhanced comparability of our results with our peers. I believe this change will be the final piece of the puzzle to allow our stakeholders to better compare our performance to that of our competitors. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Cameron.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Fiscal 2016 was another terrific year for Global Payments, and included a number of significant milestones. We executed our largest ever transaction in our merger with Heartland, successfully raised $4.5 billion t
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. Fiscal 2016 was another terrific year for Global Payments, and included a number of significant milestones. We executed our largest ever transaction in our merger with Heartland, successfully raised $4.5 billion to finance growth, completed our first stock split in 10 years and lastly we're added to the S&P 500 index. Importantly, we accomplished all of these, while also producing strong financial performance throughout the year. 
Total company net revenue for fiscal 2016 was $2.17 billion, reflecting growth of 11% versus fiscal 2015, or 17% on a constant currency basis.
Operating margin expanded 50 basis points to 29.2%. On a constant currency basis, operating margin expanded 120 basis points. 
Cash earnings per share increased 18% to $2.98 per share, or 29% on a constant currency basis. For each of these measures, we exceeded our cycle guidance on a stated databases and substantially exceeded it on a constant currency basis. 
For the fourth quarter, total company net revenue was $621 million, a 25% increase over the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015, or 27% on a constant currency basis. Operating margin was 28.1%, an expansion of 40 basis points. On a constant currency basis, operating margin expanded by 70 basis points. 
Cash earnings per share grew 14% to $0.73, or 16% on a constant currency basis. Relative to our expectations in April, currency impacted fourth quarter cash earnings per share by roughly $0.01 to $0.02. 
Naturally, fourth quarter performance reflects the results of Heartland from April 22, which were in line with the expectations we shared during our April call. 
Now for detailed segment highlights for the quarter. Our North American segment, which now includes Heartland, saw net revenue growth of 36% and operating margin expansion of 30 basis points, despite unfavorable currency trends in Canada. On a constant currency basis, operating margin expanded by 50 basis points. 
Normalized organic net revenue growth in our U.S. direct channels calculated as if we owned Heartland and the FIS gaming business in both this period and in fiscal 2015 was high single digits for the quarter. 
Canada once again delivered solid growth in local currency, in line with expectations. The weak Canadian dollar impacted North American net revenue growth by over 100 basis points for the quarter. 
As Jeff noted, our European business performed well again this quarter, posting revenue growth of 7% on a constant currency basis. Reported net revenue growth for Europe was 3% due to significantly unfavorable foreign currency exchange rates, particularly the pound in Europe. As a reminder, we also annualized our acquisition of Realex in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016. 
European operating margin was 47.8%, declining from prior year, primarily due to investments we are making to further expand our omnichannel solutions business and foreign currency impacts. 
Asia net revenue grew 15% or 19% on a constant currency basis, despite ongoing macroeconomic weakness in our Greater China markets. 
Organic constant currency revenue growth, adjusting for both the BPI and eWAY transaction, was high single digits for the quarter, accelerating sequentially from our fiscal third quarter. 
Once again, we're particularly pleased with operating margins in Asia-Pacific, which expanded by over 400 basis points to 26.3%. This was primarily driven by the continued strong growth in our Ezidebit business as well as the expense management program we implemented in the fall of 2015. 
Shortly after closing the Heartland merger, we entered into a $50 million accelerated share repurchase agreement bringing total share repurchases in the quarter to 711,000 shares for approximately $53 million. Subsequent to the end of the quarter, we repurchased a further 638,000 shares for approximately $44 million.
Now turning to our fiscal 2017 outlook. On a constant currency basis, we expect fiscal 2017 net revenue to range from $3.25 billion to $3.35 billion, reflecting growth of 50% to 54% over fiscal 2016. We anticipate foreign currency headwinds will impact net revenue growth by 200 to 300 basis points for the year, resulting in expected reported net revenues of $3.2 billion to $3.3 billion. 
Operating margin is expected to expand by up to 70 basis points on a constant currency basis. After reflecting the anticipated impact of foreign currency headwinds, we expect reported operating margin to expand by up to 40 basis points. We are particularly pleased with our outlook for operating margin expansion as we expect to be able to absorb the anticipated margin degradation from Heartland and still expand operating margins on a constant currency basis toward the high end of our cycle guidance.
We expect cash earnings per share on a constant currency basis to range from $3.50 to $3.60, reflecting growth of 17% to 21% over fiscal 2016. After giving rise to anticipated foreign currency headwinds, particularly the significant weakness we have seen in the pound resulting from the Brexit referendum, we expect reported cash earnings per share to range from $3.4o to $3.50, reflecting growth of 14% to 17%. 
We are forecasting the most significant foreign currency impacts in the first 2 quarters of the year. As a result, we expect roughly 47% to 48% of our cash earnings per share to be contributed in the first 2 fiscal quarters and the balance to be realized in the back half of the fiscal year. This is essentially the inverse of fiscal 2016.
With respect to the more detailed assumptions that underlie this outlook, we expect North American net revenue to grow nearly 70% in fiscal 2017, including FX headwind from the Canadian dollar. This growth reflects the addition of Heartland and our expectations that our combined U.S. direct businesses will generate organic growth in the high single digits. Canadian net revenue growth assumptions remain in the low single digits in local currency. 
We expect to North America operating margin to expand for the year as we anticipate being able to more than offset the margin impacts of Heartland with operating efficiencies and synergies. 
In Europe, we expect net revenue on a constant currency basis to grow in the mid-teens, including the impacts of the Erste transaction. FX headwinds in Europe, especially the British pound, are forecasted to impact net revenues by several hundred basis points, resulting in expected reported growth in the high single digits. 
Operating margin in Europe is expected to decline in fiscal 2017, [indiscernible] did integration cost associated with our Erste joint venture and the impacts of foreign currency headwinds. Much of the degradation is anticipated in the first half of fiscal 2017 when we expect to realize a substantial portion of the integration-related expenses and absorb a considerable amount of the foreign currency impacts. 
Asia-Pacific is expected to deliver U.S. dollar net revenue growth in the low double digits. Operating margin is expected to remain relatively consistent in fiscal 2017 as compared to fiscal 2016. 
Our effective tax rate for fiscal 2017 is projected to approach 30%. And our diluted weighted average share count is expected to approach $156 million. We anticipated that we will invest approximately $140 million in capital expenditures in fiscal 2017.
With the completion of the Heartland merger, our near-term capital allocation priority is to reduce debt and return to our targeted leverage ratio. As such, we expect a majority of our free cash flow in fiscal 2017 to support debt reduction. However, we have sufficient capital available to continue to pursue select acquisitions that augment our strategies like the eWAY partnership we executed in Q4. You should assume we will continue to be a consistent buyer of our stock as a means by which to return capital to shareholders. That said, our outlook for fiscal 2017 does not include any assumptions with respect to future share repurchases. 
As Jeff referenced, we are pleased to announce about our Board of Directors has approved the change in our fiscal year end from May 31 to December 31. Our first fiscal year on a calendar year basis will begin January 1, 2017. As a result, we will report a 7-month fiscal period for the period June 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016. We will host our Q1 and Q2 fiscal 2017 earnings call as customary and we'll then transition to calendar quarter reporting beginning with the first quarter of calendar year 2017. With our forthcoming change in fiscal year-end, we're providing an early preview of our outlook for calendar year 2017 to assist with this transition. 
Building off of our constant currency guidance for fiscal 2017, we would preliminary expect constant currency net revenue of approximately $3.375 billion to $3.5 billion for calendar 2017. In addition, we would anticipate cash earnings per share on a constant currency basis to be in the range of $3.75 to $4 for calendar 2017. 
I will now turn the call back over to Jeff.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cameron. Building on the solid foundation from fiscals 2014 and 2015, we delivered yet another year of strong results in fiscal 2016. As our fiscal 2017 and cycle guidance post Heartland suggest, we remain committed to accelerating growth across o
componenttext:
Thanks, Cameron. Building on the solid foundation from fiscals 2014 and 2015, we delivered yet another year of strong results in fiscal 2016. As our fiscal 2017 and cycle guidance post Heartland suggest, we remain committed to accelerating growth across our markets. 
We've had a terrific run over the last several years but we are just as optimistic today as we were back in October of 2013. We have the right people in right places with the right business model. Early results of our partnership with Heartland, our largest investment to-date, points strongly toward continued success for fiscal 2017 and beyond. We could not be more pleased with where we are today, but more importantly, we could not be more excited about where we are headed. Andrew?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Lots of numbers to digest, but I guess at a high level maybe you could sort of frame how you thought about and included in your fiscal '17 and calendar '17 guidance the -- both the Heartland Payments cost synergies and revenues synergies, how should we be thinking about that?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, it's Jeff, I'll start and I'm sure Cameron and David will add. First on the cost [indiscernible] side, as I said in the releasee this morning, we're well down the path of where we expect to be on expense synergies, in particular relative to the $50
componenttext: Sure, it's Jeff, I'll start and I'm sure Cameron and David will add. First on the cost [indiscernible] side, as I said in the releasee this morning, we're well down the path of where we expect to be on expense synergies, in particular relative to the $50 million that we talked about in fiscal '17. Today, we believe we're running ahead of that target of $50 million for fiscal 2017 realization. That fall the buckets that we talked about back in December and April, primarily on the executive side, on the operating side and on the technology side. on The revenue enhancements, as you know, at the time that we announced the transaction, December as well as in April, we talked about 1% to 2% incremental revenue growth over the cycle. As I mentioned in my prepared remarks, we've already had some early wins coming work out of our work with the folks over at Heartland, but we haven't yet included that in our fiscal '17 estimates as we have not included those in the guidance we gave in December and April. Cameron, you want to...

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the only other thing I would add there Glenn is as we look at synergies on the expense side for fiscal '17, as Jeff noted, we are ahead of the target that we originally established back in December when we announced the transaction. Perhaps, more impo
componenttext: No, the only other thing I would add there Glenn is as we look at synergies on the expense side for fiscal '17, as Jeff noted, we are ahead of the target that we originally established back in December when we announced the transaction. Perhaps, more importantly, however, I think we're very much on track to realize the full run rate synergies that we had targeted with respect to the transaction, the $125 million in fiscal '18 and beyond. So I think from an expense point of view, we feel very good about where we are, have a lot of positive momentum going into fiscal '17 to exceed the expectations we had for the full year. But as I said before, we're very focused on that ultimate run rate number and are well on track to achieve that expectation.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Glenn it's David, I'd made a little more color on the revenue. I think I've said the same thing about revenues that jeff and Cameron said about expenses. I think we're a little ahead of where we might have thought we'd be right now. Those obviously ta
componenttext: And Glenn it's David, I'd made a little more color on the revenue. I think I've said the same thing about revenues that jeff and Cameron said about expenses. I think we're a little ahead of where we might have thought we'd be right now. Those obviously take a little bit longer to execute, require obviously closings sales, et cetera, in some cases, some product development. But if you told me a few months ago, we've already closed our first cross boarded deal in Canada, I would have been surprised. Really pleased as to where the sales force are working together. So we are equipping that Heartland sales force to do cross-borders as we speak with an initial focus on Canada, followed by Europe and the U.K. We're also adding in targeted, I would call, the surgical addition to sales folks in white space territories that don't have full coverage, which is outside of the plan and kind of a unique synergy we've run across in the last few months. And maybe as interesting to go back to some of the things we've talked about in earlier calls, we're enabling the technology businesses, the software businesses like TouchNet, the campus solutions business to sell software and Global Payments processing in Canada and Puerto Rico with U.K. and Europe to follow shortly and the same for the commerce businesses around the world and beginning to process of enabling those going forward.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the other question, I'll ask a couple and I'll jump back in the queue. But as it relates to the revenue synergies, is it early to sort of be thinking about potential pricing benefits? Or have you thought about and the timing of that? And the other ques
componenttext: So the other question, I'll ask a couple and I'll jump back in the queue. But as it relates to the revenue synergies, is it early to sort of be thinking about potential pricing benefits? Or have you thought about and the timing of that? And the other question is on related to the synergies maybe just sort of the OpenEdge expectation into '17 of what you're assuming in terms of the benefit from the European or the U.K. interchange reduction, are you going to keep that, like some other people peers are parsing back? And I'll jump back in.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Glenn, I'll first couple items. As it relates to pricing, there's no assumption in our fiscal '17 guidance for any sort of pricing changes with respect to the apartment portfolio, so that's a fairly easy one to address. With respect to your second ques
componenttext: So Glenn, I'll first couple items. As it relates to pricing, there's no assumption in our fiscal '17 guidance for any sort of pricing changes with respect to the apartment portfolio, so that's a fairly easy one to address. With respect to your second question around interchange, the interchange benefits came into effect in December as we talked about in the U.K. Obviously, the interchange benefit themselves are transitory benefits as they have been in other markets where we've seen such changes over the course of time, including the U.S. back in 2012 and, of course, Spain in 2014. So over the course of time, we do expect the markets to rationalize as pricing benefits. We're seeing in the U.K. what we expect to see and have seen in other markets as it relates to these transitory benefits. Over time they'll get rationalized away and spreads will return to preinterchange reduction levels over 12 to 18 months time frame and I think the U.K.'s very much on that track currently. One element to note with the U.K. is we did see some early adoption of the [indiscernible] rule in Q4 '15. So these reduce some debit interchange, excuse me, in Q4 '15. MasterCard also reduced some credit interchange in fiscal 2015. So we have started to begin to annualize some of the early benefits from SEPA but the largest change obviously came into effect in December of '15.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also on the OpenEdge, our assumptions, fiscal '17 is that it continues that mid to high-teens rate of growth that we've been ascribing probably over the last 2 to 3 years.
componenttext: Also on the OpenEdge, our assumptions, fiscal '17 is that it continues that mid to high-teens rate of growth that we've been ascribing probably over the last 2 to 3 years.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when we run that through and you talk about Europe being down, Asia flat, and I look to this kind of organic growth of high single digit in North America and we certainly are layering in the cost synergies, it sounds like there might be maybe meaningfu
componenttext: So when we run that through and you talk about Europe being down, Asia flat, and I look to this kind of organic growth of high single digit in North America and we certainly are layering in the cost synergies, it sounds like there might be maybe meaningful cost that you guys are taking out of the core business, is that right to assume that, in order for you to have 40 basis point increase? And if so, I'm just wondering how sustainable or how quickly is that coming through?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Dan, I'd point you to our cycle guidance that we updated on the heels of the Heartland transaction where we indicated over the cycle we expect to be able to expand margins by up to 75 basis points annually. So I think the constant currency
componenttext: Well, I think, Dan, I'd point you to our cycle guidance that we updated on the heels of the Heartland transaction where we indicated over the cycle we expect to be able to expand margins by up to 75 basis points annually. So I think the constant currency guide that we provided today is towards the high end of that expectations. I think we're particularly pleased with that, as we said before because, as you know, Heartland comes in at a lower margin than Global Payments operated at historically. So I think we've been able to absorb with that degradation and expand margins this year at a level consistent with our cycle guidance on a constant currency basis. So I think when you roll it all together, we obviously are expecting margin expansion in North America. We are expecting a little bit of margin headwind in Europe, as I noted on the prepared remarks, largely as a result of integration cost for the Erste transaction and currency. In Asia, we expect to maintain the significant margin improvement that we achieved in fiscal '16. When you roll that together, Vista, with North America no being almost 70% of the combined business, the margin expansion in North America really drives the total company margin expansion.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's great. So your organic growth of high single-digits again in North America, how do we parse that in terms of you guys consolidating share up with maybe the integrated model increasingly, volumes and then pricing opportunities. I know you said
componenttext: Yes, that's great. So your organic growth of high single-digits again in North America, how do we parse that in terms of you guys consolidating share up with maybe the integrated model increasingly, volumes and then pricing opportunities. I know you said [indiscernible] reprice the Heartland portfolio but that continues to be a pretty strong number in a market that I think secularly isn't growing that fast. So maybe you you could parse that a bit?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think I'd start with, Dan, both us and Heartland pre transactional we're growing at a faster rate than the market rate grow. So I think when we put it these 2 businesses together and able to accelerate growth that the way we believe, I thin
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think I'd start with, Dan, both us and Heartland pre transactional we're growing at a faster rate than the market rate grow. So I think when we put it these 2 businesses together and able to accelerate growth that the way we believe, I think we feel very good about that high single-digit organic revenue guide -- organic revenue growth guide for fiscal '17. If you deconstruct the parts a bit, our core direct distribution businesses in the U.S., which includes our traditional go-to-market, [indiscernible] business, OpenEdge, our gaming business, again, still growing high single digits, that's our expectation next year, led obviously by OpenEdge, as jeff mentioned earlier, which we continue to expect to grow in the mid- to high-teens level. If you look at the Heartland side, again, their direct sales business, we expect to grow high single-digit consistent with the trends we've seen in that business. The integrated businesses [indiscernible] are growing double-digit. You roll all that together, again, and you have a business that's very well poised to grow organically in the high single-digit range in fiscal '17 and beyond and it's consistent with the cycle guidance we provided historically.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Dan, it's Jeff, I would just, as I said in my prepared remarks, we announced the Heartland deal December, it closed in April. Here we are sitting in July and as I mentioned in the prepared commentary, that Heartland has experienced one of the stronges
componenttext: And Dan, it's Jeff, I would just, as I said in my prepared remarks, we announced the Heartland deal December, it closed in April. Here we are sitting in July and as I mentioned in the prepared commentary, that Heartland has experienced one of the strongest periods of the sales growth since April the last 3 months, we'll post the announcement and into the close so we couldn't be more delighted with the ongoing rate of performance that Heartland as well as our legacy global business. So it's [indiscernible] see a scenario we know something in December you don't see that kind of acceleration, but we have seen exactly that kind of acceleration into Heartland gets a lot of confidence heading into fiscal 2017.

componenttextpreview: Just want to ask about Europe. I think Europe grew 7% constant currency, that was down from a big quarter last year, or last quarter, I think it grew 16%. So just trying to figure out the delta change there on the top line in Europe?
componenttext: Just want to ask about Europe. I think Europe grew 7% constant currency, that was down from a big quarter last year, or last quarter, I think it grew 16%. So just trying to figure out the delta change there on the top line in Europe?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bryan, it's Cameron, I'll lead off. There's really 2 things. first of all, in Q3, it was 15% on a constant currency growth basis. And that included inorganic growth from Realex, which we didn't have this quarter as Realex annualized in the fourth qua
componenttext: Yes, Bryan, it's Cameron, I'll lead off. There's really 2 things. first of all, in Q3, it was 15% on a constant currency growth basis. And that included inorganic growth from Realex, which we didn't have this quarter as Realex annualized in the fourth quarter. So that's a big chunk of the difference as a starting point. I would say the second element that impacted Europe in Q4, as I mentioned earlier in my comments, we started to begin to annualize some of the early benefits from interchange reductions in the U.K., in particular. Last year, MasterCard, in the fourth quarter of '15, lowered credit interchange from on average roughly 100 bps to 80 bps. And Visa changed, debit interchange from [indiscernible] transaction to 20 basis points plus the [indiscernible]. So those early benefits from the SEPA regulation that didn't become effective until December, we began to annualize in Q4 of this year, which created a little bit of headwind. Europe still grew high single digits on a constant currency basis, that's in line with our overall expectation for Europe, so I would say it was quarter Europe was that was very much consistent with our overall expectations.

componenttext: Yes, that's a good question Bryan. So we do expect Europe to grow next year in the high single-digits on an organic basis. And then, of course, the Erste joint venture is adding inorganic growth to top line revenue expectations for different fiscal '17. So those would be the component pieces next year.

componenttext: Bryan, it's Jeff. I think you'll also see Spain finally start to annualize the annualization of the original benefit starting on September 1. So as I mentioned in our prepared remarks that yet another double-digit [indiscernible] transaction growth quarter. I think our fifth consecutive in the quarter in a market that's probably growing half that. And you're finally going to see that accelerate into the beginning of our second fiscal quarter in '17.

componenttext: Okay. And then just to close the loop here. On the international operating margin, they fell a little bit on a year-over-year basis and obviously, were done sequential. Just any -- I figured also has to do with some of the pieces on the top line we talked about. But anything else to talk about there that caused the drop in the international operating margins? And congrats on the quarter.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bryan, I appreciate it. No, I think, you got it right. Obviously currency had a fairly significant impact on margins, particularly in Europe. The other item I mentioned in my prepared remarks, again, relates to investments we're making in our e-co
componenttext: Thanks, Bryan, I appreciate it. No, I think, you got it right. Obviously currency had a fairly significant impact on margins, particularly in Europe. The other item I mentioned in my prepared remarks, again, relates to investments we're making in our e-com, omni-channel solutions business in Europe. We're continuing to invest in that platform. We are preparing to launch a bundled solution in Spain similar to what we launched in the U.K. earlier in the fall, that's coming in the next few months. So we did make investments to prepare for that market rollout, which we think will be obviously be helpful to accelerate the growth in Spain. So those investments were a little bit of a drag on margin in Q4. But on the grand scheme of things, we really try to target margin expansion for the total company, which once again we achieved this quarter. And we're very pleased with the level of margin expansion that we achieved in the fourth quarter of 2016. Europe nearly being 50% margin our goal is to largely sustain or close to sustain that level of margin and really looking to drive total company margin expansion through North America primarily.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Steven Kwok with KBW.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of mine had been answered but just want to go back on Brexit in terms of the contingencies. Can you just talk a little bit about the contingencies that you've had in place? And if things were to, say, to deteriorate further, what are the other steps
componenttext: Most of mine had been answered but just want to go back on Brexit in terms of the contingencies. Can you just talk a little bit about the contingencies that you've had in place? And if things were to, say, to deteriorate further, what are the other steps that you can say?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steven, Hi, it's Jeff, I'll start. And as I said on our commentary, we anticipated that this might happen even though it wasn't our preferred option. As a result immediately after the referendum, we took a number of steps by way of contingency to pre
componenttext: Yes, Steven, Hi, it's Jeff, I'll start. And as I said on our commentary, we anticipated that this might happen even though it wasn't our preferred option. As a result immediately after the referendum, we took a number of steps by way of contingency to prepare the business in the event that the macro environment in the U.K. deteriorate further, those were along the lines of a bit of deferral some investments we were going to make Stephan by way of headcount and product in the U.K. and Ireland. We also had planned for the event that things change further. We also have plans to make additional decisions around our European businesses if that's what's needed. I would say though if you back up, that hasn't happen today. So as we said in our commentary that post-Heartland, our U.K. business is single digits as a matter of revenue of our businesses. I think we've shown with what we have done in Asia over the last year that to the extent that there are emerging had was that we'll get ahead of those as we get in the fall of 2015 in Asia. So I think sitting here today, we are as well positioned us could be and of his they we're here to manage proactively if things change but it does not the case today.

componenttext: Got it. And you mentioned on the call around select acquisitions. Could you talk about what are some of the opportunities that you're seeing that's out there?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Sure, Steven, it's Jeff. So as always, we start with what's available for sale. We're really looking for things that are wheelhouse from a strategic point of view and have the right partnership and culture to really drive the business forward relative to our alternatives for our capital. I would say sitting here today a number of this opportunities are really in the Asia-Pacific region. Cameron I think talked about at the eWAY transaction that, that we consummated in the fourth quarter of '16, driving additional omni-channel and e-commerce activity in Australia and New Zealand. We're looking at a bunch of technology-related businesses in Asia, primarily, obviously, we think we are recently follow-up here post-Heartland in North America and then, and measure we just close our Erste JV on fair amount to continue to that integration over the next year to come. So I think we look at opportunities in sitting here today those are likely to be more weighted towards Asia but of course, we are flexible and it depends on what comes available for sale.

componenttext: Maybe just to kind of kick things off appreciate your talking about calendar '17 and kind of given of the constant currency guide $3.75 to $4, but could you also give us a sense of what that might be in a reported basis kind of what you're thinking there?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, it's Cameron. I'll start. You can see from our fiscal '17 guide that we're forecasting anywhere maybe $0.10 to $0.15 of currency headwind in fiscal '17 as a result of primarily weakness in the pounds stemming from the Brexit referendum in the U.K.
componenttext: George, it's Cameron. I'll start. You can see from our fiscal '17 guide that we're forecasting anywhere maybe $0.10 to $0.15 of currency headwind in fiscal '17 as a result of primarily weakness in the pounds stemming from the Brexit referendum in the U.K. So you can sort of extrapolate that further into calendar '17. But sitting here today on July 28, it's very difficult, I think with any sort of accuracy to what currencies may do in calendar 2017. Frankly, as some point, I hope to annualize these fairly significant headwinds. I sort view flat as the new up from a currency point of view. So I think when you get to flat, you can kind of get a sense from the guide we've given for calendar '17 is the earnings power of the business that we're able to generate notwithstanding the headwinds over the past couple of years weakened normal FX environment, obviously, 20% of cash earnings per share growth on a constant currency basis is fairly attractive and well ahead of our cycle guidance and wealth and of what I think our peers and other participants are able to produce.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, that's fair. And just kind of moving on, focusing again on the U.S. market, just what are your expectations in fiscal '17 for ISO growth? And then, are you guys thinking, I know right now, with all the confusion going on with the EMV certification and the like, but as you think about calendar '17, would you consider implementing EMV noncompliance fees?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start with the ISO comment, that's the easier question. I'll give David the hard question around EMV. On the ISO side, we're expecting essentially flat growth or roughly no growth out of the ISO channel. As we talked about historically with the bid
componenttext: Let me start with the ISO comment, that's the easier question. I'll give David the hard question around EMV. On the ISO side, we're expecting essentially flat growth or roughly no growth out of the ISO channel. As we talked about historically with the bid that we've made to direct distribution, partisan the heels of the Heartland transaction where we've essentially invested over $4 billion now in direct distribution in the U.S. market, that is the focus of our business going forward. It's obviously the driver of the growth. We'll continue to serve our ISO partners well, but that is not a focus for our business. And we're certainly not expecting any tail winds from the ISO channel we expected to be relatively flat.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then George, on EMV plans, our focus today has been on the transition for our customers, making it seamless and really delivering to them security solutions bundles that really can drive maybe nominal market share gains. So I would the way to look at
componenttext: And then George, on EMV plans, our focus today has been on the transition for our customers, making it seamless and really delivering to them security solutions bundles that really can drive maybe nominal market share gains. So I would the way to look at what Cameron and jeff had been describing, there is no assumption of economic EMV whatsoever. So that is something exploring. As we get deeper into '17, we're sitting to think about where there is our industry where we've had customer being compensated, but is now we're in the expectations just something for us to think about as a marketing matter.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

So whomever stuff them with these type of things you guys, whether it's opinion or some other delays, it's not Global Payments.

componenttext: I guess I wanted to ask first just about Canada. You talked about launching OpenEdge there and some of the cross-border business. Is it your expectation that, that growth rate there could accelerate at some point or just can you just talk about that the little bit?

componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, this is David. Our expectation is that indeed that we can accelerate Canada with really a couple of things. One is bringing in these new global initiatives like more e-com business certainly, the fastest-growing part of that market and certainl
componenttext: Yes, Paul, this is David. Our expectation is that indeed that we can accelerate Canada with really a couple of things. One is bringing in these new global initiatives like more e-com business certainly, the fastest-growing part of that market and certainly with OpenEdge, we were up to 30 partners. And we're just really beginning to build that sort of purpose built ecosystem I talked about before, partners, campaign management and our sales teams to accelerate growth, so early-stages. Hence you've seen from Cameron very traditional Canadian expectations for now for '17, which I'm expect our Canadian team to beat a this year and then beyond that, it to the Heartland synergies, so being able to take the products, whether it's education produce, with their e-commerce point-of-sale cloud software across of border Canada and just being able to take that U.S.-based customers and prospects that our Heartland sales force will close in the coming months and quarters and take those and expand those into Canada's was a with a group that, that will accelerate Canada of really for the first time in the last 5 years in Global Payments.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good to hear. Thanks for that detail. And I guess just as a follow-up, you also talk about some e-commerce enablement. And I'm wondering if you can talk about, in the U.S., your e-commerce strategy, how important is that? How you think you can get
componenttext: That's good to hear. Thanks for that detail. And I guess just as a follow-up, you also talk about some e-commerce enablement. And I'm wondering if you can talk about, in the U.S., your e-commerce strategy, how important is that? How you think you can get bigger there? Is that something that you really want to go after?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's certainly we want to go after. It's obviously a growth pool in the United States. And it's one of the hidden benefits of the Heartland transaction, to be frank. First off, we finally have a real substantial direct sales force in United States, a
componenttext: Yes. It's certainly we want to go after. It's obviously a growth pool in the United States. And it's one of the hidden benefits of the Heartland transaction, to be frank. First off, we finally have a real substantial direct sales force in United States, a strategic distribution asset that we didn't have to before. We also have OpenEdge, which is a fantastic business in our vertical gaming and [indiscernible] businesses that we've not had a direct sales force like this. And another hidden benefit of Heartland, they have a true e-commerce solutions in the United States as well, great product folks, a great development team and actual product and market that's seeing success. In fact, we actually signed a record number of e-commerce customers in Heartland during the June quarter as well. So we're seeing increasing momentum that fuels our confidence both by integration overall and the type of accelerated growth the 2 companies can deliver that Cameron described earlier.

componenttext: Wondered if we can dig in a little bit on sort of the North American you specifically the U.S. competitive environment with regard to ISO your competitors talk about ramping sales and marketing this morning around that business and other fast growth channels. So I wondered if you might just talk about perhaps the residuals in that business? And then also if you have any view on the PayPal Visa relationship? And whether or not you'd expect perhaps PayPal to try to become a merchant of record in physical world, if that's something you thought about internally?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Andrew, it's David, I'll start with some of the integrated ISP talk. Obviously, [indiscernible] highly competitive, but I don't think there's a sea change at all in the competitive nature of what's going around ISPs and integrated payments. I think,
componenttext: Yes, Andrew, it's David, I'll start with some of the integrated ISP talk. Obviously, [indiscernible] highly competitive, but I don't think there's a sea change at all in the competitive nature of what's going around ISPs and integrated payments. I think, in particular, if you think about the results we've posted in '16, our confidence in Heartland to-date and then the expectations for '17 we're expecting another mid- to high-teens delivery from OpenEdge. They continue to drive across the new verticals. We don't see some of the larger competitors describing in our specific verticals in the OpenEdge business. We continue to drive that growth in the [indiscernible] things we've talked about. Again, highly competitive radio is competitive space, but we've been more our fair share with the integrated solutions we drive. On the Heartland side, you've got the education verticals. The 2, the one for our K-12, one for university, that combination, double digits as well and the same thing, competitive deals that we're driving and winning more than our share. I think the final piece of this is really the commerce businesses where we've got new assets where we're just beginning to pursue restaurant hospitality. There, we're going to see more competition, but it's all going to be incremental for us so we are excited growth opportunity on that side.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, it's Jeff, on Visa PayPal, we're very good partner of both Visa and PayPal. I think anything that drives toward more adoption and hard-based usage, what it's relative to a say, it's cash and check consider is really nothing but good news for our b
componenttext: Andrew, it's Jeff, on Visa PayPal, we're very good partner of both Visa and PayPal. I think anything that drives toward more adoption and hard-based usage, what it's relative to a say, it's cash and check consider is really nothing but good news for our businesses. I would note that in that partnership, quarter, that's a U.S.-only deal, Visa and PayPal as a way to describe externally most of our business with PayPal, as you probably know, is outside of the United States and mostly outside of North America, primarily in Europe and Asia. So I don't think by itself it's going to have an impact because of the geography that at described, I think as a concept, to get to your other point, the idea that there's more volumes going through digital wallets, through 2 partners like Visa and PayPal, is really nothing but good news for our business in the long term.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like you're running ahead of plan on both revenue and cost synergy for Heartland, which is obviously good to hear. So should we assume that you may do better than the mid-single-digit EPS accretion target from Heartland in fiscal '17? Or what
componenttext: So it sounds like you're running ahead of plan on both revenue and cost synergy for Heartland, which is obviously good to hear. So should we assume that you may do better than the mid-single-digit EPS accretion target from Heartland in fiscal '17? Or what's actually baked into the fiscal '17 guide, is it's still the mid-single or is it something a little north of that?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, it's Cameron, I'll maybe start with that one. So if you think back to December when we originally announced the Heartland transaction, consensus for us for fiscal '17 was around 3 32 and we guided to mid-single-digit accretion, which kind of g
componenttext: Yes, Jason, it's Cameron, I'll maybe start with that one. So if you think back to December when we originally announced the Heartland transaction, consensus for us for fiscal '17 was around 3 32 and we guided to mid-single-digit accretion, which kind of gets you to 3 47 or so. If you think about where we are now, we just guided on a constant currency basis 3 50 to 3 60, so a midpoint of 3 55, that kind of implies high single-digit accretion year 1, which is pretty attractive from our point of view and obviously an acceleration from what we originally announced on the deal in the December time frame. Obviously, we've seen $0.10 maybe plus of incremental FX headwinds, so there's a little bit of noise around FX. But on an apples-to-apples basis, we're kind of looking at fiscal '17 being high single-digit accretion from Heartland and that's pretty exciting.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's real helpful. And then just 2 other quick ones related to fiscal '17, just your plans for growth in that direct sales force as well as the interest expense expectations?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David here, we do plan to keep growing sales force. It's measured. It's surgical. As I said a little while ago, we've identified white spaces where we want to accelerate growth in sales coverage as we speak. So we will keep growing that the sales force, m
componenttext: David here, we do plan to keep growing sales force. It's measured. It's surgical. As I said a little while ago, we've identified white spaces where we want to accelerate growth in sales coverage as we speak. So we will keep growing that the sales force, measuring it against demand and opportunity. But there's a lot of room for growth in terms of just headcount as well as a some coverage that you'll see in the coming quarters.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the interest expense side, I think we've provided a little bit of color around interest rate expectations back in the Q3 call. We added about $2.8 billion of incremental debt associated with the Heartland transaction [indiscernible] pay a little bit of
componenttext: On the interest expense side, I think we've provided a little bit of color around interest rate expectations back in the Q3 call. We added about $2.8 billion of incremental debt associated with the Heartland transaction [indiscernible] pay a little bit of that off over the course of the year. Our weighted average cost of debt is around 3 75 to 4, so in that ballpark. And then as a reminder, the legacy debt that we had was repriced as well as part of transactions, so there's probably incremental 100 basis points on that. So it's going to be in the same sort of probably 3 50 range for the historical debt. So all in, that gets you to an interest rate expense assumption that's it's going to be in the north of $160 million range for fiscal '17.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from David Koning with Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is from David Koning with Baird.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a couple of things. First of all, is Spain, I know you're growing pretty well there transactions and volume, has revenue caught up with that? And if not, like when does revenue catch up with the same transaction volume growth?
componenttext: I guess a couple of things. First of all, is Spain, I know you're growing pretty well there transactions and volume, has revenue caught up with that? And if not, like when does revenue catch up with the same transaction volume growth?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's Cameron, great question. Revenue is essentially flat now. So we have caught up in the sense that we've got revenue to flat to slightly up. As we get into September and annualize the annualization of the interchange benefit, I know it gets comp
componenttext: David, it's Cameron, great question. Revenue is essentially flat now. So we have caught up in the sense that we've got revenue to flat to slightly up. As we get into September and annualize the annualization of the interchange benefit, I know it gets complicated, we would expect revenue growth to trend back to the same level of transaction volume growth that we're seeing in that market, which is double digits to mid-teens. So we're very bullish on our execution in Spain. We, I think, are looking at our fifth consecutive quarter of growing transactions and volumes in the double digits where we're going well above the rate of market growth and couldn't be more delighted with our partnership with [indiscernible]. And we see nothing but really with tail winds in that market. GDP has remained very solid in of the markets and our execution has been terrific. So as we get into fiscal '17, and get past the first quarter, we expect Spain revenue growth to return to that double-digit level. And it's obviously an important driver for our overall expectations for European organic growth in fiscal 17.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Okay. And then, the minority interest a little tough because there's some moving parts in and out, now the Erste coming on. How do we think of that on a cash earnings basis in fiscal '17?
componenttext: Great. Okay. And then, the minority interest a little tough because there's some moving parts in and out, now the Erste coming on. How do we think of that on a cash earnings basis in fiscal '17?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, it is a tough thing to model. And we've had joint venture that we've unwound. We've added new joint ventures and I recognize that, that's complicated. So with the addition of Erste, I would expect it to be up year-over-year relative to fiscal
componenttext: Yes, David, it is a tough thing to model. And we've had joint venture that we've unwound. We've added new joint ventures and I recognize that, that's complicated. So with the addition of Erste, I would expect it to be up year-over-year relative to fiscal '16 in aggregate by roughly 50% relative to what we just reported for fiscal '16. So that's kind of a rough guide. And we can obviously provide a little bit more color on it that's if we have an offline conversation.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my question is about the cadence of how we think of 1Q and 2Q, I guess, the other current quarter will be part of the new calendar reporting. The reason I asked is last year's August quarter was pretty much the perfect quarter and very strong. So can y
componenttext: So my question is about the cadence of how we think of 1Q and 2Q, I guess, the other current quarter will be part of the new calendar reporting. The reason I asked is last year's August quarter was pretty much the perfect quarter and very strong. So can you help from modeling perspective with that?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ashwin, it's Cameron. I tried to give a little bit of color on that in my prepared remarks because we were recognize a couple of things. One is the quarterly distribution of ratings in fiscal '17 because of the FX headwinds, in particular, are likely
componenttext: Yes, Ashwin, it's Cameron. I tried to give a little bit of color on that in my prepared remarks because we were recognize a couple of things. One is the quarterly distribution of ratings in fiscal '17 because of the FX headwinds, in particular, are likely to be sort of the inverse of what we saw in fiscal '16. So we expect 47% to 48% of the earnings to be distributed in the first 2 quarters combined and the balance, 52% to 53% in the back 2 quarters, which to your point will roll into the new calendar year. For the full fiscal '17 guide, obviously, we're going to see the most FX headwinds in Q1 and Q2, in particular, but primarily, Q1. So still expect growth in Q1 over fiscal '16 and same for Q2. But it will ramp in the back half of the year as we hope currency headwinds will begin to abate, number one. And number two, it's important to recognize that synergies ramp over the course of time as well. So as we're executing on synergies and taking expenses out of the business, the benefits of those actions ramp up over the course of the fiscal year as we roll into the fiscal '18 as well. So those 2 things combine, create an environment where the back half will be a little bit stronger than the first half but the overall expectations for the year, I think, are very, very attractive.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess that's a good segue to the next question I had, which is synergy question. So if I think of the $50 million synergy for fiscal '17, that you're making investment basically for the first half of the year, that would imply fairly strong mo
componenttext: Okay. And I guess that's a good segue to the next question I had, which is synergy question. So if I think of the $50 million synergy for fiscal '17, that you're making investment basically for the first half of the year, that would imply fairly strong move from investment to benefit to the letter have, which would mathematically seem to carry us to synergy pace about $125 million. And I think you partly addressed this in the previous reply with regards to the EPS guidance. But why not just bring up with the synergy target at this point if you're already seeing that is the question?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ashwin, it's a really good question. So what I would start with is when we look at our fiscal '17 expectation, there's a lot of activities that are in progress today. Now we have dollar amounts tied to every one of those activities, but there's obvio
componenttext: Yes. Ashwin, it's a really good question. So what I would start with is when we look at our fiscal '17 expectation, there's a lot of activities that are in progress today. Now we have dollar amounts tied to every one of those activities, but there's obviously execution that needs to be done to realize those synergies. So as we sit here today, we expect to achieve synergies in excess of the original $50 million-ish guide that we provided when we originally announced the deal in fiscal -- or at the end, I'm sorry, of December for fiscal '17. But more importantly, as I said in my comments earlier, we're well on track to meet the overall run rate synergy expectations by at the time we get into fiscal '18 and beyond of $125 million a year. As you know, with synergies, you have realized synergies in particular period but you also measure the run rates of the actions you have taken and how their country but into the overall run rate expectation that we have of $125 million. So I think it's a little early to, I think, try to put more specific numbers around where we think we're going to end up from a synergy point of view, but I want would want to leave you with certainly our perspective, which is we have a high degree of confidence on being able to exit of synergies for fiscal '17 relative to what we originally anticipated in and certainly feel very, very confident in our ability to deliver on the total of run rate synergy that we had the premise in the original transaction economics.
