componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Global Payments Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, today's conference will be recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to your host, Vice President, Investor Relations, Isabel Janci. Please go ahead.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Global Payments Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Conference call. Our call today is scheduled for 1 hour. Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that some of the comments made by management during today's conference call contain for
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Global Payments Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Conference call. Our call today is scheduled for 1 hour. Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that some of the comments made by management during today's conference call contain forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties discussed in our SEC filings, including our most recent 10-K and any subsequent filings. These risks and uncertainties could cause actual results to differ materially, and we caution you not to place undue reliance on these statements. Forward-looking statements made during this call speak only as of the date of this call, and we undertake no obligation to update them. To better conform with recent SEC guidance regarding the disclosure of non-GAAP measures, we now refer to cash operating margin and cash earnings as adjusted operating margin and adjusted earnings, respectively. There has been no change to the calculation of this measures. Some of the comments made on this call refer to these and other non-GAAP measures such as adjusted net revenue and free cash flow, which we believe are more reflective of our ongoing performance. For a full reconciliation of these and other non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures and accordance with Regulation G, please see our press release furnished as an exhibit to our Form 8-K filed this morning and our trended financial highlights, both of which are available in the Investor Relations area of our website at www.globalpaymentsinc.com. 
Joining me on the call are Jeff Sloan, CEO; David Mangum, President and COO; and Cameron Bready, Executive Vice President and CFO. Now I'll hand the call over to Jeff.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Isabel, and thanks, everyone for joining us this morning. We are delighted to report a strong start to our fiscal 2017 continuing the positive momentum we have seen in our business. We accelerated organic growth across our key markets during the f
componenttext:
Thanks, Isabel, and thanks, everyone for joining us this morning. We are delighted to report a strong start to our fiscal 2017 continuing the positive momentum we have seen in our business. We accelerated organic growth across our key markets during the first quarter with particular strength in Heartland, OpenEdge and our United Kingdom and Asia businesses. While delivering these results, we also made substantial progress integrating Heartland and are ahead of our expectations in realizing synergies from the merger. 
For the first quarter, we delivered high single digit organic direct net revenue growth and adjusted earnings per share growth of 15% on a constant-currency basis. We are also particular pleased with our ability to expand operating margin in North America, which includes the addition of Heartland for the full quarter. 
Our North American businesses performed very well in the quarter led by our U.S. direct sales channels, which generated high single digit organic net revenue growth. This was primarily driven by strength in new sales at Heartland and OpenEdge, each of which accelerated sequentially. Further, Heartland achieved an all-time new sales record in August demonstrating continued momentum in that channel. 
In Europe, we generated strong local currency revenue growth in the first quarter, including double-digit growth in our U.K. business, which accelerated from the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016. 
Spain delivered impressive results and we, again, saw double-digit volume and transaction growth well in excess of the rate of market growth. We also continue to make strides advancing our e-commerce and omni solutions businesses in Europe, and I'm delighted to announce that we are now live with Realex in Spain. 
Our businesses in Continental Europe, including our joint venture with Erste Bank [ph] in central Europe that closed in early June performed in line with our expectations. 
Lastly, Asia's performance in the first quarter was exceptional. We accelerated organic net revenue growth to the low double digits resulting in the highest rate of growth in this market in several quarters. Our traditional Asia markets performed very well and once again, our Ezidebit business contributed meaningful to results in the region with over 20% organic growth this quarter. 
Just 5 months since closing in our partnership with Heartland, we've established our go-to-market strategy across distribution channels and verticals, identified new opportunities to accelerate revenue growth and have began rationalizing corporate support, operating and technology environments. The progress we have made demonstrates our continued relentless focus on execution, which positions us well to achieve synergy targets, and importantly, to drive a number of incremental growth initiatives. 
We are already realizing revenue enhancements through our various distribution channels here in the United States and abroad. In addition to initial cross sales in Canada we discussed in July, we are now sharing sales leads from Heartland with all of our regions around the world. In the U.S., we have combined our traditional direct sales forces and have configured our platforms to be able to sell either Global Payments or Heartland Payment solutions to new customers. We have also enabled both our Campus Solutions and Heartland commerce point-of-sale software products on Global Payments platform in Canada opening up opportunities for both new sales and the migration of existing Heartland software customers to Global Payments. 
Finally, our investment in enhancing our School Solutions technology platform supported record payments volume growth and flawless execution during the peak school enrollment season. Given our extensive planning, focus and strong execution, we are also realizing expense synergies ahead of initial expectations. We have made significant progress in merging corporate functions, consolidating facilities and operating centers and developing our future technology architecture model for key systems across the combined organization. 
As part of this effort, we selected Heartland's Jeffersonville facility as our go forward U.S. operating center and plan to close our Owings Mills facility by early calendar 2017. This allows us to leverage Global Payments worldwide, unified operating environment in the Jeffersonville facility to create a scalable world-class service center to support our global operations. 
Lastly, we are completing  our migration plans to consolidate our technology environments to achieve our future state model, which is critical to achieving our full expense synergy expectations. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Cameron.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We reported another quarter of strong financial performance, while also making significant progress on our Heartland integration efforts and executing synergy plans ahead of expectations. Total company net reven
componenttext:
Thanks, Jeff, and good morning, everyone. We reported another quarter of strong financial performance, while also making significant progress on our Heartland integration efforts and executing synergy plans ahead of expectations. 
Total company net revenue for the first quarter was $817 million, a 52% increase over the first quarter of fiscal 2016. Operating margin was 29.5%, or 29.9% on a constant-currency basis consistent with our expectations for the quarter. Adjusted earnings per share was $0.86 for the first quarter, reflecting growth of 9% or 15% on a constant-currency basis. 
Our North America segment grew net revenues by 79% compared to the first quarter of fiscal 2016 and operating margin expanded 80 basis points despite the inclusion of Heartland, which has a lower-margin profile relative to Global Payments' historical levels. We are practically pleased with our ability to expand margins in North America as this is the first period that includes Heartland for the full quarter. 
Normalized organic net revenue growth in our U.S. direct sales channels calculated as if we own Heartland in both this period and in the first quarter of fiscal 2016 was high single digits for the quarter. This was primarily driven by our Heartland sales channel, which generated high single digit organic growth and OpenEdge, which produced yet another quarter of mid-teens growth. 
Canada again, delivered solid performance with low single digit growth in local currency consistent with our expectations. The Canadian dollar remained the headwind in the quarter, albeit less severe than we experienced in fiscal 2016. 
Our European business performed very well this quarter delivering 11% net revenue growth on a constant-currency basis. Reported growth for Europe was 2% compared to the prior year due to significantly unfavorable foreign currency exchange rates, particularly the pound which declined nearly 14% year-over-year. Growth in Europe was primarily driven by low double digit net revenue growth in the United Kingdom and the continued expansion of our e-commerce and omnichannel solutions businesses as well as the addition of the Erste joint venture. 
European operating margin of 47.9% declined from the previous year as expected due primarily to integration cost associated with the Erste transaction and foreign currency impacts. As we noted in our July call, we anticipate a significant portion of these integration costs in currency headwinds will be realized in the first half of fiscal 2017. 
As expected, we have yet to see a real impact on our business resulting from the U.K. EU referendum, except, of course, for the devaluation of the pound. In fact, as Jeff noted, our in the U.K. accelerated this quarter despite the outcome of the referendum. We will continue to monitor developments going forward to assess potential implication for our business. 
As Jeff mentioned, Asia-Pacific had an outstanding quarter with 17% net revenue growth and operating margins of 28.4% an increase of 50 basis points year-over-year. Growth in Asia was primarily driven by low double-digit organic growth in the region, including Ezidebit as well as the addition of the BPI joint venture and Eway [ph]. 
Excluding Heartland integration cost, we generated free cash flow of approximately $107 million this quarter. We define free cash flow as net operating cash flows, excluding the impact of settlement assets and obligations less capital expenditures and distributions to noncontrolling interests. 
Capital expenditures totaled $38 million for the quarter. In addition, we reduced outstanding debt during the first quarter by $44 million and since the date of our last call, we repurchased an additional 379,000 shares for $28 million. 
Our current share repurchase authorization capacity is $191 million. As a reminder, we continue to expect to use the majority of our free cash flow this year to support debt production. 
As Jeff mentioned, our integration of Heartland is tracking ahead of schedule, and we now expect to realize over $60 million of expense synergies in fiscal 2017 as compared to our prior estimate of over $50 million. We are delighted with the progress we are making and have been able to execute on the planned synergies more quickly than previously assumed further positioning us to achieve our full expected run rate synergies from the merger. 
Given the strong performance in the first quarter, and our updated expectation for synergy realization for the year, we are increasing our outlook for fiscal 2017. We now expect adjusted earnings per share to be in the range of $3.45 to $3.55, reflecting growth of 16% to 19% over fiscal 2016. In addition, we now expect operating margin to expand by 50 basis points for the year. 
We continue to expect net revenue to range from $3.2 billion to $3.3 billion or growth of 47% to 52% over fiscal 2016. It is worth noting this outlook reflects our expectation that foreign currencies will be marginally weaker for the remainder of the year relative to our forecast when we guided back in July. 
I will now turn the call back over to Jeff.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cameron. From the offset, the goal of our integration has been to ensure a frictionless culmination of the 2 businesses, building on the momentum that Global Payments and Heartland have each had individually. Although we are still early in the pro
componenttext: Thanks, Cameron. From the offset, the goal of our integration has been to ensure a frictionless culmination of the 2 businesses, building on the momentum that Global Payments and Heartland have each had individually. Although we are still early in the process, we could not be more pleased with the progress we have made. Not only are we ahead of our expectations with respect to integration, we have accomplished this while accelerating revenue growth at Heartland, which will help drive overall revenue and earnings per share growth for the combined company. Isabel?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask about the European margins. What kind of an impact did Erste JV have, can you quantify that and the currency headwinds in the quarter? And then is the outlook for margins is to stay sequentially similar in the second quarter and then im
componenttext: Just wanted to ask about the European margins. What kind of an impact did Erste JV have, can you quantify that and the currency headwinds in the quarter? And then is the outlook for margins is to stay sequentially similar in the second quarter and then improve in the second half? And if it improves in the second half, what drives that?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bryan, it's Cameron. I'll start and then ask either Jeff or David to add any other thoughts they may have. So I would say in the first quarter, the margin declined in Europe were pretty much exactly what we anticipated. And if you look at the 2 primary dr
componenttext: Bryan, it's Cameron. I'll start and then ask either Jeff or David to add any other thoughts they may have. So I would say in the first quarter, the margin declined in Europe were pretty much exactly what we anticipated. And if you look at the 2 primary drivers, one being Erste and our integration efforts specifically around the Erste joint venture and the second being currency, they probably each contributed about a half of the decline in margin that we saw in Europe, that 450 basis points in the first quarter. So about half and half coming from Erste and currency. I think as you worked through the year I would expect that to get progressively little bit better. Some of the FX headwinds will begin to abate as we get into the back half of the year. And as we continue with the integration efforts on Erste, I would expect most of that work to be done in the first few quarters of the year such that by the time to we get to Q4, sitting here today, I would anticipate we'd be back to flat to expanding margins in Europe, which as we talked about in the past with margins nearing 50%, our objective in Europe is really to sustain that level of margin, not really looking to expand those margins for that particular segment.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, I would just to what Cameron said that as we mentioned in our release, our businesses in Europe performed exceptionally well this quarter. Our U.K. business accelerates revenue growth into double-digit. You may also recall that Spain has now double
componenttext: Jeff, I would just to what Cameron said that as we mentioned in our release, our businesses in Europe performed exceptionally well this quarter. Our U.K. business accelerates revenue growth into double-digit. You may also recall that Spain has now double annualized the interchange reductions as of September 1. So going forward to Cameron's point, we expect continued growth and revenue profitability in our Spanish business, which has been a bit of a headwind over the last 12 months.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, terrific and just a quick follow-up. On the synergies from Heartland, could you guys increased those $10 million for this fiscal year? Is that just, to clarify, it's just that pull forward from the total run rate of synergies? Or is that an addition
componenttext: Okay, terrific and just a quick follow-up. On the synergies from Heartland, could you guys increased those $10 million for this fiscal year? Is that just, to clarify, it's just that pull forward from the total run rate of synergies? Or is that an additional increase in the synergies for what you think you're getting at in Heartland and maybe what is causing the pull forward?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bryan, I'll jump in there. I would say, as it relates to the expense synergies themselves, what we're really seeing thus far is an acceleration of our plans. So we're realizing synergies in fiscal '17 more quickly than we otherwise anticipated that we cou
componenttext: Bryan, I'll jump in there. I would say, as it relates to the expense synergies themselves, what we're really seeing thus far is an acceleration of our plans. So we're realizing synergies in fiscal '17 more quickly than we otherwise anticipated that we could. I think it's a little premature to suggest that the overall run rate, the full expected run rate synergies that we expect from the merger will be higher than the target we provided when we announced the deal last December. But I would say obviously, the progress we're making gives us a tremendous amount of confidence that they have the right momentum towards in achieving that target and potentially exceeding that over time.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ashwin Shirvaikar of Citigroup.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The question I have, you have pretty good revenue performance coming out of multiple parts of your business. Is it just basically too early in the year [indiscernible] outlook seeing, or is the FX [indiscernible] the underlying business? Any color with re
componenttext: The question I have, you have pretty good revenue performance coming out of multiple parts of your business. Is it just basically too early in the year [indiscernible] outlook seeing, or is the FX [indiscernible] the underlying business? Any color with regards to how comfortable you are with the upper [indiscernible] part of the range?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Cameron, I'll jump in and I'll just note we had a trouble hearing you. I think you're asking about the revenue guide and why the revenue guide perhaps wasn't increased in the quarter. I think inherently, you can think of it as an increase because we
componenttext: It's Cameron, I'll jump in and I'll just note we had a trouble hearing you. I think you're asking about the revenue guide and why the revenue guide perhaps wasn't increased in the quarter. I think inherently, you can think of it as an increase because we are now forecasting more FX headwind than we were when he guided in July. So I think you're going to essentially look at it as an implicit increase. We're absorbing more FX setting on the top line yet maintaining that overall revenue guidance of $3.2 million to $3.3 billion. We did obviously increased our expectation around margin expansion for the full year as well, which is driving obviously, the increase in earnings per share guidance [indiscernible]. So I think we do see obviously revenue tracking ahead of what we would have anticipated but we're also currently forecasting more FX headwind than we were back in July, is the short answer.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then with regards to OpenEdge, at what point might you expect to see some benefit to the Canada growth rate, you are rolling outlook [ph] [indiscernible] Canada are beginning to see some benefits in terms of market share, and so on?
componenttext: Got it. And then with regards to OpenEdge, at what point might you expect to see some benefit to the Canada growth rate, you are rolling outlook [ph] [indiscernible] Canada are beginning to see some benefits in terms of market share, and so on?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ashwin, it's David on this one. It's a great question. We are beginning to see real progress and tangible progress in Canada. We got the full rollout now with integrated solutions there. We actually signed new partners, we're building the pipeline. S
componenttext: Yes, Ashwin, it's David on this one. It's a great question. We are beginning to see real progress and tangible progress in Canada. We got the full rollout now with integrated solutions there. We actually signed new partners, we're building the pipeline. So I would say to these really feel good about the seeds we're planting in Canada to accelerate solid revenue growth in Canada. We expect to see the benefit of that really this year and certainly in calendar '17, begin to see some of those trends upward in our favor.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Georgios Mihalos of Cowen.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Georgios Mihalos of Cowen.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to start off sort off piggy backing a little bit on Ashwin's question. You started the year with the revenue growth rate of 52% sort of the upper end of the 47% to 52% that you guided to. And then I would think the comparison as we go to 2Q and 3Q
componenttext: I want to start off sort off piggy backing a little bit on Ashwin's question. You started the year with the revenue growth rate of 52% sort of the upper end of the 47% to 52% that you guided to. And then I would think the comparison as we go to 2Q and 3Q get a little bit easier year-over-year than what you had in the first quarter. Is there any reason why at least over the next 2 quarters, the revenue growth rate should increase from the 52%?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Cameron. I think your thesis is right. I would remind you that when we get to Q4, we obviously are going to annualize Heartland for part of Q4. So naturally the growth rate in Q4 is not going to be at that 47% to 52% range. But they think it's fair t
componenttext: It's Cameron. I think your thesis is right. I would remind you that when we get to Q4, we obviously are going to annualize Heartland for part of Q4. So naturally the growth rate in Q4 is not going to be at that 47% to 52% range. But they think it's fair to say during Q2 and Q3, you need to factor in currencies, I'll remind of that, but the comps are a little easier relative to Q1, but I think your overall thesis is correct as it relates to slight acceleration of revenue growth in those 2 quarters relative to what we saw on Q1.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just point of clarification, Cameron. I think you have said at least in the pro forma basis, the direct North America business or direct U.S. business was up high singles again, which is what you guided to for the year. Did you break that
componenttext: Okay, great. And just point of clarification, Cameron. I think you have said at least in the pro forma basis, the direct North America business or direct U.S. business was up high singles again, which is what you guided to for the year. Did you break that out for what legacy GPN business was before Heartland? And maybe you can size that Heartland contribution in revenue for us for the quarter?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, first of all, you're correct. We did note that the U.S. direct business grew high single digits in line with our expectations, including Heartland, of course, on a normalized basis. Breaking out the component, I would say, is a little more difficu
componenttext: George, first of all, you're correct. We did note that the U.S. direct business grew high single digits in line with our expectations, including Heartland, of course, on a normalized basis. Breaking out the component, I would say, is a little more difficult, not really feasible by virtue of the fact that we are combining these businesses. And as more time progresses, the more difficult it's going to be to look at the business in the U.S. in particular, and say, what was legacy Heartland and what is legacy Global Payments. As we talked about on the call, we've already combined our direct sales forces in the U.S. market so where do I attribute that growth that's being driven by the combination of our direct sales forces, we combined our traditional direct book with Heartland's direct book. So it's a little difficult to say specifically what Heartland drove in the quarter versus what Global Payments drove. We did, however, achieved the overall expectation we have for the business, which is growing our U.S. direct sales channels in that high single digit range, which we are obviously very pleased with, while also continuing to make progress on progressing some of the revenue enhancements and revenue synergies that we expect to achieve over time.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jim Schneider of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jim Schneider of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: May be following up on some of the metrics you gave regarding Heartland. Can you've maybe -- I understand it's how to break out from the organic global business, but can you maybe give us some color around how the Heartland working base growth was in the
componenttext: May be following up on some of the metrics you gave regarding Heartland. Can you've maybe -- I understand it's how to break out from the organic global business, but can you maybe give us some color around how the Heartland working base growth was in the last 3 quarters and how that's kind of track in terms of growth rates just [indiscernible] basis versus what they're reporting at the end last year?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Jeff. I'll give some overall color and I think Cameron and David can provide some additional details. So as you in our prepared commentary, Heartland had one of the best sales month ever in August in terms of sales momentum and that's a continuation
componenttext: It's Jeff. I'll give some overall color and I think Cameron and David can provide some additional details. So as you in our prepared commentary, Heartland had one of the best sales month ever in August in terms of sales momentum and that's a continuation of the trend that I think we talked about in our July call as we talked about our outlook for fiscal 2017. So I said sitting here since we announced the deal in December of '15 and closed in April of '16, the opportunity we've had to talk with you guys, talk with guys twice about it, Heartland is only accelerating that growth as it relates to new sales over that period. I'd also say in terms of the health of the merchant base that Heartland, the attrition is running low relative to their own expectations and our own expectations going into the deal as well. So as Cameron mentioned in his remarks, our ability to accelerate their growth, minimize any merchant or sales rep disruption, while taking the expense actions that we've taken on a combined basis is something that we're practically pleased about by way of [indiscernible].

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I'll add, Jim, it's Cameron, if you look at Heartland's other business outside of the pure payments business, you look at campus solutions, school solutions, Heartland commerce, each of those continue to perform very well also. We see good
componenttext: The only thing I'll add, Jim, it's Cameron, if you look at Heartland's other business outside of the pure payments business, you look at campus solutions, school solutions, Heartland commerce, each of those continue to perform very well also. We see good momentum in those businesses. We like those businesses a great deal. The vertical specific approach that they have through those channels aligns well with our integrated strategy, we believe and remain excited about the performance of those business. And lastly, they also performed very well in the quarter. We continue to see good momentum utilizing the Heartland sales force to be able to cross-sell payroll solutions across the customer base and into new customers going forward. So I think we're very pleased overall with how Heartland performed in the quarter relative to our expectations.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is David, I'll add a few pieces, see what's already missed, thorough answer. When we think about running the business, we're running one business in United States right now. So an answer Cameron gave earlier is exactly right, it's the way we're manag
componenttext: This is David, I'll add a few pieces, see what's already missed, thorough answer. When we think about running the business, we're running one business in United States right now. So an answer Cameron gave earlier is exactly right, it's the way we're managing the business. We have one U.S. sales force for general payments. It's also a fantastic start post the acquisition. As Cameron correctly said, payroll is accelerating, the payments are accelerating -- the additional products are accelerating. But the other products, the other business units are having record sales as well with its Campus Solutions; School Solutions, where we've just had the fastest-growing back-to-school season in Heartland's history; all of those operating well, executing well despite as you might imagine what can be a tumultuous time around the synergy integration overall. The business is a focus, the leadership is a focus. We're really feeling good about the momentum we have right now.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And maybe follow on your comment there, David. If you look at the overall ability to drive sales in the U.S. through increased investment in sales and marketing, and you weigh that against the cost synergies, you're obviously getting at a
componenttext: That's helpful. And maybe follow on your comment there, David. If you look at the overall ability to drive sales in the U.S. through increased investment in sales and marketing, and you weigh that against the cost synergies, you're obviously getting at a plan with Heartland, how do you think about when those 2 things if you think you can put dollar extra investment in the sales force and margin activities to grow the U.S. business faster? How do you offset that against what you had basically think that you couldn't take any additional excess synergies from the Heartland deal and replow those back into those activities?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question when we talk about all the time here sort Of the balance of sales productivity, products investment, synergies. We're really fortunate in a couple of ways. One is Heartland fits beautifully into our overall strategy of running an ope
componenttext: It's a great question when we talk about all the time here sort Of the balance of sales productivity, products investment, synergies. We're really fortunate in a couple of ways. One is Heartland fits beautifully into our overall strategy of running an operating company, creating leverage, getting on common platforms, and chasing that capital that result in benefits and pouring into products and distribution, that's exactly the calculus we're really running everyday when we think about where to go from here. So I'll give a couple of examples. While the teams are working hard on how we combine platforms, I know we put call centers together and what we do to better serve customers more efficiently, our sales teams and our marketing teams are working on actually driving the top line growth. You can do both at once. For example, we ordered the first Heartland merchant to a global payments platform, that took a fair amount of technology investment, can puts us well ahead of platform migration, makes the platform migration not an emergency as we get to that over the next year or so that allows our Heartland sales force to be that much more productive. They can now sell the entire sphere of product that Global Payments and Heartland have together and the products don't -- perfectly overlap. There are some VAR integration that Heartland doesn't have, Heartland couldn't sell a CyberSource gateway integration, for example, Heartland do not have cash advance product like Global Payments has. All of these things can now be sold by that 1,500-person sales force. We can now sell in Canada and Puerto Rico out of that by enabling the platform, by having our teams work on that while separate teams are working on expense synergies and driving more and more efficiencies out of the infrastructure. So we're spending an awful lot of time in these parallel tracks, planting a lot of seeds, hitting a lot singles on the way to what we expect, which is really going to be accelerating growth above what we think it can be over the next couple of years with these enhanced sales capabilities. Beyond even that, we're making little investments like accelerating sales hirings. Sales reps are up a little bit over where they were when we closed the deal, that's conscious. We're filling in white spaces that weren't covered. That the choice we made Global Payments with the Heartland leadership team, an opportunity to invest a little early in what can become nice calendar '17 sales in areas really underserved by our combined sales force of the date. We're sharing leads, as Jeff said in his comments with Hong Kong, U.K., Canada, that doesn't take anything away from our ability to perform our synergy work and get to our expense synergies at all. In fact, it's just wonderful volume to put at the top of this very efficient engine we run. Heck, we've automated the sales lead sharing process with half [ph] with Canada. And as you might imagine, that's a likely place for a lot of volume to come overtime. So we really feel good the way we're putting selective targeted investment back into the sales model, while being able in parallel to keep driving our synergies and not in any way degrade customer service. So the pieces are working well together right now.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Steven Kwok of KBW.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Steven Kwok of KBW.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering around the revenue synergies that you previously talked about where you can get additional 1 to 2 percentage points over time. Where are we with that? And is all initiatives that you have in place is what the ultimate goal is? Or can it do
componenttext: I was wondering around the revenue synergies that you previously talked about where you can get additional 1 to 2 percentage points over time. Where are we with that? And is all initiatives that you have in place is what the ultimate goal is? Or can it do better than that 1 to 2 percentage points?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Cameron, I'll maybe jump in there. I think David gave a very wholesome answer as it relates to qualitatively what we've been doing to drive revenue enhancements across our U.S. businesses. The thing that I would add is sitting here today, it's import
componenttext: It's Cameron, I'll maybe jump in there. I think David gave a very wholesome answer as it relates to qualitatively what we've been doing to drive revenue enhancements across our U.S. businesses. The thing that I would add is sitting here today, it's important to note that the revenue enhancements we've achieved thus far, they're on the helpful in the margin, but they're not significant enough to really move the needle as of yet. David talked about continuing to invest in these opportunities such that over time, we expect to be able to realize the 1% to 2% incremental revenue growth target that we provided when we announce deal generated from revenue enhancements, so $30 million to $60 million or so. It's going to take some time to scale these as you talk about combining disruption platforms, combining technology environments to efficiently create opportunities across our products and enhance the revenue growth of the combined business credits going to take time to scale back to a point where you're seeing a more meaningful impact from the revenue enhancements actually on our performance. But we expect over the next couple of years to get to that point, and we do continue to believe that the overall revenue synergy target that we provided again, is a realizable target, and I think we have great momentum early toward achieving that ultimate goal.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe I'll add a little more color. I think that's exactly of the summary that drives our strategy and integration when we think, Steven, about how to go out the synergies. Certainly, my expectations you get out to the time frame that Cameron is talki
componenttext: And maybe I'll add a little more color. I think that's exactly of the summary that drives our strategy and integration when we think, Steven, about how to go out the synergies. Certainly, my expectations you get out to the time frame that Cameron is talking about will be the high end of those and we're certainly shooting to beat that rate. In addition to the direct sales synergies, the real strategy if we think about Heartland combined with Global Payments is going to all the way across all of the Heartland global assets, figuring out how to combine the best of both and then globalize everything. So very much as Cameron said, we're very much in the mode of planting seeds, things [indiscernible] work now that will bear the fruit '17 to '18 and beyond. In addition to the direct sales synergies I described earlier, we're doing the same thing with Campus Solutions. Our TouchNet software platform, the one that powers Campus Solutions is now integrated with Global Payments, our technology platforms in Canada, that means we can sell net new customers. We can go back and to touch that existing customer base and sell merchants on payment, payments from Global Payments and we're beginning to build a pipeline. That same platform is now certified for Puerto Rico. We're ready to go in Puerto Rico as well. So as you can see again, planting a few more seeds. The same what's been historically called the Heartland commerce, the point-of-sale cloud software solutions. We just certified our retail point-of-sale solutions for Canada, again, for payments in Canada. We have 40 dealers in Canada now with portfolios. We can look to migrate those to our payments. We can obviously sell net new. We're working with target markets then in Europe and Asia to continue expanding that. Lots of really good exciting activity that at this moment is very much at the margin that Cameron directly says, it's deals here and there, it's pipelines building, all with the focus on that 1% to 2% again being at the high end of that range or beating that range over time.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey of SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Andrew Jeffrey of SunTrust.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder just expanding a little bit on some of the nice sales commentary on Heartland integration commentary. Cameron, you had talked about through the cycle of organic revenue growth rate, given everything you're seeing at Heartland and also it sounds l
componenttext: I wonder just expanding a little bit on some of the nice sales commentary on Heartland integration commentary. Cameron, you had talked about through the cycle of organic revenue growth rate, given everything you're seeing at Heartland and also it sounds like continued momentum in OpenEdge, is it reasonable to think about North America perhaps being a structurally faster geography for Global?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is. If you think about the cycle guidance that we provided historically, Andrew, the single-digit rate of organic growth, that's obviously what we believe this business can produce over time. With North America now being 75% of the business, if
componenttext: I think it is. If you think about the cycle guidance that we provided historically, Andrew, the single-digit rate of organic growth, that's obviously what we believe this business can produce over time. With North America now being 75% of the business, if it's not growing near that level it's going to be very difficult for the overall company to grow at that level. So I think it's fair to say that is our goal as we think about our North American business more broadly. That doesn't mean Canada is going to be anything different than what we expected to be, which is a low single grower in local currency, hopefully, Canadian dollar headwinds will abate here at some point. But we do believe as we continue to obviously progress, the combination of Heartland and Global Payments in the U.S. with North America should accelerate towards that level, allowing the overall company to achieve the high single digit rate of organic net revenue growth that we expect to achieve over the cycle.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And with regards to OpenEdge and Heartland commerce, again, maybe qualitatively, at least, can you talk about how those 2 initiatives are working together versus may be just coexisting given that they're going after some of the similar distribution
componenttext: Okay. And with regards to OpenEdge and Heartland commerce, again, maybe qualitatively, at least, can you talk about how those 2 initiatives are working together versus may be just coexisting given that they're going after some of the similar distribution partners but have slightly different strategies, one being vertically integrated in Heartland commerce and may be a little bit of channel strategy for OpenEdge. How do 2 those things kind of coexist versus see potential synergies?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Andrew, it's David, I'll take the first pass at this. But actually, coexisting, beautifully, right now. In fact, they're working directly together on our go-to-market strategies, particularly as we think about some of our large competitors in the int
componenttext: Yes, Andrew, it's David, I'll take the first pass at this. But actually, coexisting, beautifully, right now. In fact, they're working directly together on our go-to-market strategies, particularly as we think about some of our large competitors in the integrated space that we can chase with these new assets. I remind you that when we look at volume, we look at verticals. Less than 5%, it's really actually less than 3% overlap between OpenEdge and its verticals that it serves and what we get at Heartland commerce that because Heartland commerce is primarily restaurant and hospitality, there's very little restaurant and very will hospitality in the OpenEdge portfolio. That allows us to think about a channel strategy for hospitality that really has us as the ISV working with dealers and working with direct sales to sell the combined software and payment solutions of the go-forward Global Payments. It allows OpenEdge to continue to focusing on what it does best, which is just managing the ecosystem between ISVs and merchants, working the targeted marketing to sales, adding new partners, while still working to actually add new merchants to existing partners. I'd also say OpenEdge still isn't the same position it was a year or after several years of mid-teens growth, really successful growth, we've got lots of opportunity inside the existing partner base. So we've got a nice little wall for like the better metaphor right now, Andrew, between the market served really by commerce and the commerce assets and the markets served by OpenEdge. And as we bring more and more cloud technology to market, we can be more and more thoughtful and surgical with our channel strategies and again, chase some of to big players in hospitality, which we think is a real opportunity for sales growth over time as well.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Condra of credits ways.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Condra of credits ways.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the EPS guidance. I think Cameron, you'd said for calendar 2017, you're thinking $3.75 to $4 of FX neutral. Can you just give us a little update on that just in light of your guidance revision today?
componenttext: Just on the EPS guidance. I think Cameron, you'd said for calendar 2017, you're thinking $3.75 to $4 of FX neutral. Can you just give us a little update on that just in light of your guidance revision today?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, it's Cameron. We're not updating that early preview that we gave for calendar '17 back in July. The $3.75 to $4 on a constant-currency basis relative to fiscal '16 was really designed to help you guys and the market in general with the transiti
componenttext: Yes, Paul, it's Cameron. We're not updating that early preview that we gave for calendar '17 back in July. The $3.75 to $4 on a constant-currency basis relative to fiscal '16 was really designed to help you guys and the market in general with the transition to a new calendar year but we're not specifically updating that today. We are naturally updating our fiscal '17 guide, as you correctly stated, rising that from $3.40 to $3.50 to our current $3.45 to $3.55. So I think that obviously suggest very good momentum as we're going into calendar '17, and you can draw your own conclusion from that. I think the one obviously item that we continue grapple with is FX headwind. And as is suggested on the call today, we believe, even in that guide, in that raised guide, on cash earnings per share, excuse, adjusted earnings per share, that we're going to be absorbing more FX headwinds in those results. So as we get to calendar '17, early calendar '17 we'll provide a guide for calendar '17 that obviously reflects our expectation for the business as well as what we think the obviously FX impacts will be for the calendar period.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. And then on the OpenEdge business. I think you talked about it today being kind of a mid-teens grower and in the past, you've mentioned mid- to high teens. So I just -- can you clarify, is there any change in trajectory there or anything you
componenttext: Okay, thanks. And then on the OpenEdge business. I think you talked about it today being kind of a mid-teens grower and in the past, you've mentioned mid- to high teens. So I just -- can you clarify, is there any change in trajectory there or anything you're seeing?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, no. There's no real change in trajectory. Depending on the quarter kind of bounces around between mid- and high. As we think about the business, our expectation is that business continues to grow in the mid-teens level. We feel very good abou
componenttext: I would say, no. There's no real change in trajectory. Depending on the quarter kind of bounces around between mid- and high. As we think about the business, our expectation is that business continues to grow in the mid-teens level. We feel very good about the momentum and the trajectory to be able to do that. But from one quarter to the next, it may be high teens, it maybe mid-teens, but generally in that ballpark is what our expectation is for the business. So I would tell you for Q1, they performed exactly in line with our expectations, and it accelerated relative to Q4, which I think is very good points of emphasis.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from David Togut of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: And our next question comes from David Togut of Evercore ISI.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could comment more broadly on the impact of interchange caps that went into effect in Europe on December 9 of last year, in particular, is there a potential for an increase in merchant acceptance of electronic payments as a cause of p
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could comment more broadly on the impact of interchange caps that went into effect in Europe on December 9 of last year, in particular, is there a potential for an increase in merchant acceptance of electronic payments as a cause of payments have come down?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, it's Jeff. so as we said in our remarks this morning, our European businesses and, in particular, our U.K. business has performed exceptionally well during the quarter. So certainly, we think one of the important trends in the marketplace is a lowe
componenttext: David, it's Jeff. so as we said in our remarks this morning, our European businesses and, in particular, our U.K. business has performed exceptionally well during the quarter. So certainly, we think one of the important trends in the marketplace is a lower cost of acceptance as well as a good macroeconomic backdrop for those markets. As I think we've said over time, reductions in cost to our merchants are really nothing but good news for our business but those ultimately gets competed away over a period of time. So I think it's good news as their deals go down. The market tends to be efficient over periods of time. So our benefits as time goes on us tends to get compete away, yet the merchants continue to benefit with lower cost of acceptance than they had previously. It's hard to back that out of the underlying economic growth in the markets that we're in. But if you look at our experience, for example, in Spain, which early adopted the interchange reductions, here, we are now 2 years beyond the first adoption of the interchange reductions in our business has grown, as we said in our prepared remarks, probably at 1.5 to 2x the rate of market growth for each of the last 6 quarters. How much of that is attributable to the lower cost of acceptance, the fantastic partner we have in Caixa [ph], in the Spanish markets kind of hard to disaggregate. But I think there's no doubt, David, that around the world lower cost of acceptance for our customers is really nothing but a good thing.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, too, David, this is David, I'd add in the more developing markets of Central and Eastern Europe penetrated with our Erste joint venture, you find that cost of acceptance being enhancements certainly to organic growth and secular growth in those m
componenttext: I think, too, David, this is David, I'd add in the more developing markets of Central and Eastern Europe penetrated with our Erste joint venture, you find that cost of acceptance being enhancements certainly to organic growth and secular growth in those markets.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a quick follow-up, Jeff, I'm wondering what your thoughts are longer-term about Europe. As the banks see pressure from the reduction in interchange, do you see opportunities perhaps overtime to acquire some merchant portfolio in Europe as a re
componenttext: And just as a quick follow-up, Jeff, I'm wondering what your thoughts are longer-term about Europe. As the banks see pressure from the reduction in interchange, do you see opportunities perhaps overtime to acquire some merchant portfolio in Europe as a result?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, absolutely. So as we said in our remarks this morning, we're very pleased with the initial progress in our Erste joint venture, which encompasses a number of countries in Continental Europe. I do believe that part of the rational on behalf of
componenttext: Yes, David, absolutely. So as we said in our remarks this morning, we're very pleased with the initial progress in our Erste joint venture, which encompasses a number of countries in Continental Europe. I do believe that part of the rational on behalf of the Erste Bank for considering the joint venture was the change in competitive and technology dynamics in the markets in which they're in, in Continental Europe. So we certainly continue to pursue other venture partners in Europe. I think that the number of technological and market changes that you see going around Europe today do nothing but help our ability to create value for our partners. I think we've been able to show for a very long period of time in many markets how we've been able to create very good returns for our shareholders and our partners and I think the changes in Europe provides another opportunity to do the same and we expect that our partners at Erste will be similarly happy. So from that point of view, David, we continue to pursue those ventures and we do hope to do more in the future.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Bob Napoli, William Blair.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Bob Napoli, William Blair.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, you highlighted right upfront, and you talked about accelerating growth in all of your markets, and we've had very mixed retail data out of the U.S, Asia, and I think getting mixed reports on the economic trends there. And you talked about some of t
componenttext: Jeff, you highlighted right upfront, and you talked about accelerating growth in all of your markets, and we've had very mixed retail data out of the U.S, Asia, and I think getting mixed reports on the economic trends there. And you talked about some of their products and I understand that some of the acceleration. But do you feel this acceleration is driven -- do you think some of it is economic improvement? I mean, your acceleration in growth seems out of place with what generally seem to  be reported out of retail sales and economic growth and the markets you serve?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a great question. So I would say is I really think it's a combination of attacking the white markets with the right people and the right model. So in most of the markets which we compete, United States is a good example, as David deluded to, we're ve
componenttext: It's a great question. So I would say is I really think it's a combination of attacking the white markets with the right people and the right model. So in most of the markets which we compete, United States is a good example, as David deluded to, we're very specific about the markets that we go after and how we do it. So to David's response about, for example, in OpenEdge, an integrated vertical markets, we're selling technology solutions into markets like themselves like dental, veterinary, et cetera that are higher growth in the overall rate of GDP growth in the U.S. economy plus the adoption of electronic commerce. And we're doing it with better technology, better people, better services and ultimately, therefore, better margins. So I think Bob, perhaps a reflection of the  [indiscernible] market that we go about, how we attack them in our point of value differentiation relative to our peers that really is driving the financial rate of growth. I'd also say that there's an element of very good sales focus and execution. If you look at our results in Asia, for example, we get to really lap some of the macroeconomic headwinds that you saw starting in the second quarter of our fiscal last year in Asia, yet business is usual. Asian markets, for us, accelerate their growth, as Cameron and I each noted. In Canada, I just think that's very sales execution, in markets like Singapore and Malaysia and the Philippines with and without our partners at BPI. So the conscious investments we've made, Bob, as a company into markets that are large, diverse and growing with higher rates of vertical market growth and the average and better margin opportunities are really paying dividends, and that's why I think you're seeing in our results. Conversely, we're really not in the large merchants category, for example, in the United States with some of our peers are. And I think a lot of the data, Bob, that you're referring to reflects the large retailer, for example, market which in general is not a market we're perpetually focused at either at legacy Global or at Heartland.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And my follow-up question is, I mean, Global and the industry, as a whole, to some of your competitors have had a great run since 2013, in particular. What is -- how -- what are you most worried about as far as disrupting the strong trends that you
componenttext: Great. And my follow-up question is, I mean, Global and the industry, as a whole, to some of your competitors have had a great run since 2013, in particular. What is -- how -- what are you most worried about as far as disrupting the strong trends that you've had? How sustainable are the trends that we've seen? Or are what are you most worried about that could derail the very strong trends we've seen, is it competition? Is it regulation?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's Jeff, so I'll start and ask David and Cameron to join in as well. But I think, and we touched a lot of this in the last question that you asked, that I think what you're seeing is the result of a period of investment that we've made in our busin
componenttext: Bob, it's Jeff, so I'll start and ask David and Cameron to join in as well. But I think, and we touched a lot of this in the last question that you asked, that I think what you're seeing is the result of a period of investment that we've made in our business over period of time that's really bearing fruit. I think David very nicely described the investments we've made in sales, in Heartland and in legacy Global Payments that really resulting in dividends not just in the United States but around the world, the investments we've made in our technology environment since fiscal '12 and fiscal '13 are really bearing fruit. So from that point of view, I think we're differentiated in terms of where we place chips on the table. In terms of what we're worried about, I think it all starts with, for us, in our peers in the industry, what is the macroeconomic environment look like, most of us are GDP-plus derivative type businesses and therefore it's important that we operate in healthy economic environments. For example, we talked about much of fiscal '16 in Asia where for a number of quarters, the latter 3 quarters in fiscal '16, we've had a headwind in Greater China. I think we've been able to show throughout fiscal '16 and our results now in '17, our guidance show that we're able to take whatever actions we need to take quickly to preserve  margin and to reposition our business quickly. So there's no doubt, at the end of the day, that a healthy economy is an important driver globally of our results. So I think it's important in terms of what we worry about a health economic environment for us globally to see the growth those businesses. We also need to make the right decisions about technology investments, which is where I started. Many of the things that we invested now, we will see returns in 12, 18, 24 months from now. It's important to get those things right. So in terms of what we worry about, we worry about putting the wrong chips in the wrong place in the table such that we've made investment hadn't born fruit. Happily that's not the case. But we worry a lot is the strategy about whether it's the right investment to make today to returns in the future.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's right. I think I'd add to that technology investments, are we really helping our customers do the [indiscernible] those investment, the right investments as we go deeper into software, we believe they absolutely are bearing fruit today, but
componenttext: I think that's right. I think I'd add to that technology investments, are we really helping our customers do the [indiscernible] those investment, the right investments as we go deeper into software, we believe they absolutely are bearing fruit today, but we're thinking about those is the right way to think about servicing customers, allowing them to take care and to like their consumers at the point of interaction to point-of-sale. And obviously, in our industry you're always worried about security. We do believe that the combination of EMV [ph] encryption tokenization is great for overall healthy industry overall. Consumer confidence secular question talking about earlier I think Paul's question may be DVD surround adoption and security is a big piece of that we invest heavily trained to find the right balance as well as the returns, so we think about those couple of things in addition to what Jeff said.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Cameron, with one final comment on the same topic. It's a little bit different take. I do think we've had a great run over the last 3 years, of course, and that's been borne out by obviously, how the share prices performed. I think it's very fair to
componenttext: It's Cameron, with one final comment on the same topic. It's a little bit different take. I do think we've had a great run over the last 3 years, of course, and that's been borne out by obviously, how the share prices performed. I think it's very fair to say, sitting here today, we remain just as enthusiastic, if not more so, about the future over the next several years for this business. Obviously, the combination of Heartland is a transformational opportunity for us, but we think our ability to drive high rates of organic revenue growth in the business, expand margins and compound double-digit mid-teens growth and earnings per share obviously, creates a very nice trajectory for the business and gives us a lot of optimism about where we're heading as a company financially.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Dan Perlin of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Dan Perlin of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to may be dovetail a little bit on that last -- the comments you guys have just been making. When you look ahead and you look at the results you've had thus far, how much of this is a function, in your opinion, of your positioning in share gains
componenttext: I wanted to may be dovetail a little bit on that last -- the comments you guys have just been making. When you look ahead and you look at the results you've had thus far, how much of this is a function, in your opinion, of your positioning in share gains in the market given those chips that you've been placing and you could pick U.S. or Europe and Asia for that matter relative to real market expansion. So it goes back to kind of like secular growth versus your share gains in either mature markets or emerging markets and I would just be interested to know how you guys think about parsing that data out for your growth?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Jeff, so I'll start with that. Our bogey in most of the markets that we're in is where are Visa and MasterCard are growing transactionally, that's one way of getting a rate of market growth. For those markets that we're in, we're not in every su
componenttext: Dan, it's Jeff, so I'll start with that. Our bogey in most of the markets that we're in is where are Visa and MasterCard are growing transactionally, that's one way of getting a rate of market growth. For those markets that we're in, we're not in every sub-vertical market that Visa and MasterCard are in but where it's relevant for us what's the rate of the transaction of growth, number one. Number two, what is GDP growing in those markets plus 200 to 300 basis points of increment reflecting the transition from paper to electronic means. So if you just fill that and there's obviously a lot of market that we're in, we're in 30 countries physically today around the world, would you say, in general, across all of our markets, the bogey is around 5% market rate of growth, some are higher or some are lower. But in general, it's around 5% rate of growth. If you look at our cycle guidance, which we talked about again this morning, we target high single digit organic rate of revenue growth plus margin expansion, et cetera. So the way about it Dan is if we're targeting high single digits, if the rate of market growth is 5%, and we talked about this last year or last October in our Investor Day, we certainly think that we're capturing share in the aggregate. Now some of that is because we're in better markets, some of that is because we think we have a good differentiated sales force, some of that is because we think have steady operating environment, et cetera, but nonetheless, the math is the math. And I would say that in most of the markets around the world, we do think that we're capturing share. If you look at United States, for example, in our OpenEdge business, which Cameron and David just described, mid-teens growth is probably 3x the rate of mid-single digit market rate growth, more broadly speaking transactionally in the United States. Now we're not filling people growing at that rate at the end of the day, so I don't think it's just us. But certainly, I think traditional channels that we refer to as more relationship driven are not growing at mid-teens. And I certainly think it's fair to say that their market share gains in the technology enabled distribution area, whether it's Heartland commerce or whether it's OpenEdge relative to the more traditional, for example, financial institutional channel, where you see rates of growth that tend to be less than the market claw around low single digits. So I think it's been a conscious effort if you think about that the market is in each market that we're in, what the bogeys are, how are we going to invest in growth rates that are north of the market. It's for a lot of reasons, but at the end of the day it comes down to smart investment that take share.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in the Asian market, in particular, low double-digit organic growth that's been fantastic. I think you said Ezidebit has been growing 20-plus percent. Can you just remind us how we should be thinking about that trajectory throughout the yea
componenttext: Okay. And then in the Asian market, in particular, low double-digit organic growth that's been fantastic. I think you said Ezidebit has been growing 20-plus percent. Can you just remind us how we should be thinking about that trajectory throughout the year? We're going to dovetail it off in the back half at some point? Or are other dynamics that worked that we can kind of stay on this kind of trajectory which has been the market, I guess, that we've been waiting for this double-digit for a longtime and you guys are clearly putting it up, so I'd be interested to know that?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Cameron, I'll jump in there. I think we feel very good about the momentum we have in Asia sitting here today. So I don't expect a lot different in the back 3 quarters of the year. I would say, our overall target for Asia' is kind of high signal
componenttext: Dan, it's Cameron, I'll jump in there. I think we feel very good about the momentum we have in Asia sitting here today. So I don't expect a lot different in the back 3 quarters of the year. I would say, our overall target for Asia' is kind of high signal to low double. Obviously we're able to get the low double this quarter. Don't know that I would expect that every single quarter but certainly, we think we're in a place and have started to lap certainly as we get into Q2 and Q3 some of the macro headwinds in the Greater China market, that Jeff described earlier. I think we feel great about the overall prospects to be able to achieve low double-digit growth in Asia overall for the year, including high single to low double organic growth.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Tien-tsin Huang of JPMorgan.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016

componenttext: Want to dig more into the strong Heartland sales in August in the quarter. Just may be focusing more on core merchant sales, just I know you said sales synergy is good and lower attrition but anything secular cyclical to call out again the quarter as beneficial things like EMV transition bottleneck, so they are is the timing and influence, for example?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's David. There really isn't anything specific to call out. We've got terrific productivity. As I said earlier, reps are up a little bit but it's only really at the margin and the productivity coming with the additional reps is where we want it to be. S
componenttext: It's David. There really isn't anything specific to call out. We've got terrific productivity. As I said earlier, reps are up a little bit but it's only really at the margin and the productivity coming with the additional reps is where we want it to be. So it's not just a volume thing or something on those lines in terms of just more reps to create more sales. The quality of sales is good, the retention is very good right now. I think that on the pure payments basis, EMV is not driving these sales. I realize that's a popular topic of conversation but it has more to participants industry overall rather than us directly us as a payment technology provider. So I think we're very happy with the pieces. I would tell you that the combination of being able to sell other products in addition to payments does make for better, stronger sales and more sales. So selling payroll, selling some of the other products, selling our ACH [ph] base products for online customers, obviously enhances the payment sales as well. But I really -- I don't have a single thing at which to point the engines working well, the leadership is in place and the machining and tooling underlies managing this  1,500 person complex sales force is working well.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's helpful to know. And just I know there's been a couple of questions on Asia but Ezidebit, are you doing something different there in terms of distribution? Obviously, I'm just curious if that growth rate is sustainable? And if could we see it acceler
componenttext: It's helpful to know. And just I know there's been a couple of questions on Asia but Ezidebit, are you doing something different there in terms of distribution? Obviously, I'm just curious if that growth rate is sustainable? And if could we see it accelerate here by itself, Ezidebit?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tien-tsin, it's Jeff, we actually have seen the acceleration ready in the last number of quarters with Ezidebit. Part of with those a number of years ago, it's been just over 2 years now this month. We didn't model out high 20s growth. That wasn't ou
componenttext: Yes, Tien-tsin, it's Jeff, we actually have seen the acceleration ready in the last number of quarters with Ezidebit. Part of with those a number of years ago, it's been just over 2 years now this month. We didn't model out high 20s growth. That wasn't our expectation for organic revenue growth, goes right around 20%. As we sit today, they've now exceeded it for a number of quarters so j.what I would tell you is we have a fantastic management team in place in Australia and New Zealand. They have essentially taken an integrated model, which is what Ezidebit is, think of it as OpenEdge based in Australia and New Zealand and certainly relative to one of the last questions, are doing nothing but capturing share in that marketplace environment. So if you are probably look at the rate for our organic transitional growth for Visa and MasterCard and their peers in Australia and New Zealand, it would not be anywhere near 20%. So clearly, Ezidebit has very good model and a very good team and they're doing all the right things. We also did spend a lot of time talking about it because it's not organic with the integration of eway [ph] which is something we announced in April has also gone very well. I think it shows, which has 25% the online market in Australia and Zealand. I think it just shows the flexibility in the confidence level in our team in the solid New Zealand and Asia to accelerate growth while they're busy growing their own business well into 20s.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
