And the machining and tooling that underlies managing this 1,500-person complex sales force is working well.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, that's helpful to know. And just I know there's been a couple of questions on Asia. But just Ezidebit, are you doing something different there in terms of distribution? Obviously, I was just curious if that growth rate is sustainable, even -- co
componenttext: Okay. No, that's helpful to know. And just I know there's been a couple of questions on Asia. But just Ezidebit, are you doing something different there in terms of distribution? Obviously, I was just curious if that growth rate is sustainable, even -- could we see it accelerate here by itself, Ezidebit?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tien-tsin, it's Jeff. We actually have seen the acceleration already in the last number of quarters with Ezidebit. We partnered with those guys a number of years ago. It's been just over 2 years now this month. We didn't model out high 20s growth. Th
componenttext: Yes, Tien-tsin, it's Jeff. We actually have seen the acceleration already in the last number of quarters with Ezidebit. We partnered with those guys a number of years ago. It's been just over 2 years now this month. We didn't model out high 20s growth. That wasn't our expectation for organic revenue growth. It was right around 20%. As we sit today, they've now exceeded it for a number of quarters. So what I would tell you is we have a fantastic management team in place in Australia and New Zealand. They have essentially taken an integrated model, which is what Ezidebit is, think of it as OpenEdge based in Australia and New Zealand, and certainly, relative to one of the last questions, are doing nothing but capturing share in that marketplace environment. So if you were probably to go look at the rate of organic transactional growth for Visa and MasterCard and their peers in Australia and New Zealand, it would not be anywhere near 20%. So clearly, Ezidebit has a very good model with a very good team, and they're doing all the right things. We also didn't spend a lot of time talking about it because it's not organic. But their integration of eWAY, which is something we announced in April, has also gone very well, and I think it shows the -- which has 25% of the online market in Australia and Zealand. I just think it just shows the flexibility and capacity and our confidence level in our management team in Australia, New Zealand and Asia to accelerate growth while they're busy growing their own business well into the 20s.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from the line of Jason Kupferberg of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our final question comes from the line of Jason Kupferberg of Jefferies.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick ones. Is there any slight change in the tax rate guidance for the year? The only reason I ask is I know the EPS is going up by $0.05 but revenues have changed. I think the margins are going up by 10 bps. So I wasn't sure that, that
componenttext: Just a couple of quick ones. Is there any slight change in the tax rate guidance for the year? The only reason I ask is I know the EPS is going up by $0.05 but revenues have changed. I think the margins are going up by 10 bps. So I wasn't sure that, that would quite get you to the $0.05 just with the slight margin change.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jason, it's Cameron. It's a good question. The margin change obviously helps. But as I'll note, we're absorbing more FX in there as well. I think overall, tax rate, I think the expectations remains pretty much the same as what we described back in Ju
componenttext: Yes, Jason, it's Cameron. It's a good question. The margin change obviously helps. But as I'll note, we're absorbing more FX in there as well. I think overall, tax rate, I think the expectations remains pretty much the same as what we described back in July. We think it's going to approach 30%. It was 28.5%. So 28.5%, 29%, something in that ballpark, sort of approaching kind of the high 20s to 30% range remains our expectation for tax rate. I would say the guide itself doesn't suggest an increase -- or, excuse me, a decrease in the effective tax rate. That not what's driving the increase in the guide. It's really the Q1 performance, coupled with our outlook for the remainder of the year, the increase in expense synergies that we're targeting now for fiscal '17 relative to the Heartland transaction, obviously offset slightly by some incremental FX headwinds.

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you quantify the incremental FX headwind? I mean, are we talking like 0.5 point here in the top line? Or is it closer to a full point?
componenttext: Can you quantify the incremental FX headwind? I mean, are we talking like 0.5 point here in the top line? Or is it closer to a full point?

headline: Global Payments Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Oct 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it could be close to a full point sitting here today. Unfortunately, the pound is off 2% to 3% relative to where it was in the last 2 weeks, quite frankly. We're now seeing it go down around $1.27. It was $1.30 for most of September. It was -
componenttext: Yes, I think it could be close to a full point sitting here today. Unfortunately, the pound is off 2% to 3% relative to where it was in the last 2 weeks, quite frankly. We're now seeing it go down around $1.27. It was $1.30 for most of September. It was -- obviously a little higher on average for Q1. So I think we remain cautious probably as it relates to the pound specifically, particularly in light of the size of that business relative to the overall size of Global Payments. The unfortunate reality is a lot of other currencies tend to be trading in sympathy with the pound, it appears, as well. So we've seen weakness, albeit maybe not as severe as we've seen in the pound. We've seen general weakness across the board in most of the major currencies to which we have exposure. So I do think it could end up being almost an additional full point for the full year, particularly in light of my view and I think our view that when you get to December, I think we expect the Fed to raise. I think in a rising rate environment here in the U.S., it's going to continue to put pressure on foreign currencies relative to the U.S. dollar, which causes us, again, to bake in a little more FX headwind into our forecast for the remainder of the year.
